Select a Count Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this gateway. Click the + button to create a new Count Monitor.

property.name: DurationMonitors
property.description: Duration Monitors watch for events meeting or exceeding a configured duration. When a duration is met or exceeded, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Duration Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this gateway. Click the + button to create a new Duration Monitor.

property.name: MonitorProcessingPolicy
property.description: Select the way that the system behaves when more than one monitor is attached to a service.

property.name: RequestAttachments
property.summary: Attachment processing mode for client requests
property.description: Select how to treat client requests with attachments. The default is Strip.

property.name: ResponseAttachments
property.summary: Attachment processing mode for server responses
property.description: Select how to treat server responses with attachments. The default is Strip.

property.name: RootPartNotFirstAction
property.display: Action when required root part is not first
property.description: When streaming MIME messages, the action to take when the root part is not the first part of the message. If the root part must be first (for example to do BSP conformance checking) and the action is set to "process in order" the DP device will buffer attachments up to the root.

property.name: FrontAttachmentFormat
property.summary: Attachment processing format for client requests
property.description: Select how to interpret client requests with attachments.

property.name: BackAttachmentFormat
property.description: Select the attachment output format to backend servers.

description.p: The body of a message (that is, the payload, independent of any protocol headers) can sometimes contain MIME headers before any preamble and before the first MIME boundary contained in the body of the message. These MIME headers can contain important information not available in the protocol headers, such as the string identifying the MIME boundary. If this property is set to on, then these MIME headers will be processed by the Gateway.
Note that if this is on and there are no MIME headers contained in the message, the device will continue to try and parse the message, using the protocol header information, if available.

When this is off and MIME headers are present in the body of the message, these MIME headers will be considered part of the preamble and not used to parse out the message. If the protocol headers (such as HTTP) indicate the MIME boundaries, the device can parse and process individual attachments. If such information is not available, no attachments can be parsed from the body of the message.

The body of a message (the payload independent of protocol headers) can sometimes contain MIME headers before any preamble and before the first MIME boundary in the body of the message. These MIME headers can contain important information that is not available in the protocol headers, such as a string that identifies the MIME boundary. If this property is set to on, these MIME headers are processed by the service.
When set to on and there are no MIME headers in the message, the device continues to try and parse the message, using the protocol header information, if available.

When set to off and MIME headers are present in the body of the message, these MIME headers are considered part of the preamble and not used to parse the message. If protocol headers, such as HTTP, indicate MIME boundaries, the device can parse and process individual attachments. If such information is not available, no attachments can be parsed from the body of the message.

property.name: StreamOutputToBack
property.description: Select the desired streaming behavior.

property.name: StreamOutputToFront
property.description: Select the desired streaming behavior.

property.name: MaxMessageSize
property.summary: The maximum size of a SOAP or XML message
property.description: Specifies the maximum size of a SOAP or XML message in kilobytes. If this value is 0, no limit is enforced.

property.name: GatewayParserLimits
property.summary: Use gateway parser limits instead of XML Manager parser limits.
property.description: Use the gateway parser limits instead of the parser limits in the XML Manager for this gateway. Gateway limits override XML Manager limits.

property.name: ParserLimitsElementDepth
property.description: Defines the maximum depth of element nesting in XML parser. If any of the parser limits are set in the Gateway, they will override those on the XML Manager.

property.name: ParserLimitsAttributeCount
property.description: Defines the maximum number of attributes of a given element. If any of the parser limits are set in the Gateway, they will override those on the XML Manager.

property.name: ParserLimitsMaxNodeSize
property.description: Defines the maximum size any one node may consume. The default is 32 MB. Sizes which are powers of two result in the best performance. If any of the parser limits are set in the Gateway, they will override those on the XML Manager.

property.name: ParserLimitsForbidExternalReferences
property.summary: XML parser forbid external references toggle
property.description: Defines if the XML parser will abort when an input document specifies to resolve an external reference such as an external entity or external DTD definition.

property.name: ParserLimitsExternalReferences
property.summary: Special handling for external references in XML
property.description: Select the special handling for input documents that contain external references, such as an external entity or external DTD definition.

property.name: ParserLimitsAttachmentByteCount
property.description: Defines the maximum number of bytes allowed in any single attachment. Attachments that exceed this size will result in a failure of the whole transaction. If this value is 0, no limit is enforced.

property.name: ParserLimitsAttachmentPackageByteCount
property.summary: Maximum byte count for all parts
property.description: Defines the maximum number of bytes allowed for all parts of an attachment package, including the root part. Attachment packages that exceed this size will result in a failure of the whole transaction. If this value is 0, no limit is enforced.

property.name: DebugMode
property.description: Select the diagnostic mode for processing policies. When enabled, the display includes the Probe button. The transactions captured by the probe can be used to view the state of variables and contexts for a captured transaction.

property.name: DebuggerType
property.description: Select the probe mode.

property.name: DebuggerURL
property.description: Configures the URL for external probe mode

property.name: DebugHistory
property.description: Controls the number of transactions saved in diagnostics mode.

property.name: DebugTrigger
property.description: The probe captures transactions that meet one or more of the conditions defined by the triggers. These triggers examine the direction or type of the message flow and examine the message for an XPath expression match. When a message meets one of these conditions, the transaction is captured in diagnostics mode and becomes part of the list of transactions that can be viewed.

property.name: RequestType
property.description: Characterizes the traffic that originates from the client. The default is SOAP.

property.name: ResponseType
property.description: Characterizes the traffic that originates from the server. The default is SOAP.

property.name: SOAPSchemaURL
property.summary: Specifies which W3C XML Schema will be used to validate SOAP documents
property.description: When a firewall is in SOAP mode, either on the request or response side, it will validate the incoming messages against a W3C Schema that defines what a SOAP message is supposed to look like. It is possible to customize which schema is used on a per-firewall basis by changing this property; this can be used to accomodate non-standard configurations or other special cases.

property.name: FrontTimeout
property.summary: Idle time a front side connection is allowed before being canceled during a transaction.
property.description: Controls the amount of time a front side client connection can be idle before being abandoned within a transaction.

property.name: BackTimeout
property.summary: Idle time a back side connection is allowed before being canceled during a transaction.
property.description: Controls the amount of time a back side client connection can be idle before being abandoned within a transaction.

property.name: FrontPersistentTimeout
property.summary: Maximum Idle Time Between Front Persistent Uses
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 0 through 86400, with a default of 180) that a gateway maintains an idle persistent TCP connection on the front side.

property.name: BackPersistentTimeout
property.summary: Maximum Idle Time Between Backside Persistent Uses
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 0 through 86400, with a default of 180) that a gateway maintains an idle persistent TCP connection on the back side.

property.name: IncludeResponseTypeEncoding
property.summary: Include the character set encoding in any content-type headers
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable including the character set encoding in any content-type header or description produced. For example, when sending a UTF-8 encoded XML document: If this property is disabled, 'text/xml' will be sent. If this property is enabled, 'text/xml; charset=UTF-8' will be sent.

property.name: BackHTTPVersion
property.description: Select the HTTP version to use on the server-side connection. The default is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression functionality on backside.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on back side.

property.name: LoopDetection
property.description: Some protocols provide a loop detection mechanism that can be used to detect gateway loops. This is a good policy, but it can cause each gateway to be publically recorded in the transmitted message, which might be considered an information leak.

property.name: FollowRedirects
property.description: Some protocols generate redirects as part of the protocol - for example HTTP response code 302. If this property is enabled the gateway will try and transparently resolve those redirects.

property.name: DoHostRewriting
property.summary: Enable/Disable rewriting of host names when accessing back side server
property.description: Some protocols have distinct name based elements, separate from the URL, to de multiplex. HTTP uses the Host header for this purposes. If this feature is enabled the backside server will receive a request reflecting the final route, otherwise it will receive a request reflecting the information as it arrived at the DataPower device. Web servers issuing redirects may want to disable this feature, as they often depend on the host header for the value of their redirect.

property.name: DoChunkedUpload
property.description: Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the ability to send Content-Type Chunked Encoded documents to the back end server. When the device employs the HTTP/1.1 protocol, the body of the document can be delimited by either Content-Length or chunked encodings. While all servers will understand how to interpret Content-Length, many applications will fail to understand Chunked encoding. For this reason, Content-Length is the standard method used. However doing so interferes with the ability of the device to fully stream. To stream full documents towards the back end server, this property should be turned on. However, the back end server must be RFC 2616 compatible, because this feature cannot be renegotiated at run time, unlike all other HTTP/1.1 features which can be negotiated down at runtime if necessary. This property can also be enabled by configuring a User Agent to enable it on a per-URL basis.

property.name: ProcessHTTPErrors
property.summary: Whether to continue processing after a non-successful response from the backend

description.p: In some cases, the backend server returns a response code that indicates an error.
When enabled, the default, the DataPower service ignores the error condition and processes the response rule. If successful, returns the successful response to the client.
When disabled, the DataPower service notices the error condition and processes the error rule. If successful, propogates the response code from the backend server to the client.

property.name: HTTPClientIPLabel
property.summary: HTTP header label containing client IP address
property.description: Enter the name of an HTTP Header to read to determine the IP address of the requesting client (for example X-Forwarded-For). This value defaults to X-Client-IP.

property.name: LoadBalancerHashHeader
property.summary: Header for Load Balancer Hash Algorithm
property.description: Enter the name of an HTTP Header to use rather than a Client IP address when load balancing traffic to the back end servers using a hash algorithm. The value of the header identified here will be used to calculate a hash rather than the IP address. If this is blank, then the client IP address will be used for hash calculation.

property.name: InOrderMode
property.description: Enables in-order (serial) messaging processing for different parts or the gateway. Request rule, backend and response rule may be configured to run sequentially in respect to the order of the input messages.

property.name: WSAMode
property.description: Select the mode of Web Services Addressing (WS-Addressing). The mode specifies the WS-Addressing support that is provided by the DataPower service. The level of support is determined by the associated client and server devices. Support for a particular mode of WS-Addressing does not preclude simultaneous support for traditional addressing formats. WS-Addressing requires SOAP messages. The default is No WS-Addressing.

property.name: WSARequireAAA
property.summary: Require that an AAA policy successfully execute before establishing any new channels specified by the message.

description.p: Require successful execution of an AAA Policy before trusting the Client's WS-Addressing To SOAP header to select the server URL to connect to.

This is relevant when WS-Addressing is enabled, and the Type is dynamic-backend (dynamic routing enabled), in which case the To SOAP header determines the default URL for connecting to the back-side server.

When this property is off, and the Type is dynamic-backend, clients can route SOAP messages to any server on the backside of this gateway, which can be a significant security risk. For this reason, the default is on.

When this property is on, and the Type is dynamic-backend, if the AAA Policy runs successfully, the To address will be accepted. If the AAA Policy fails (but continues processing) the back-end address determined from configuration will be used.
If there is no AAA Policy configured (or executed) in the processing rule(s), WS-Addressing processing will proceed as if the AAA Policy had executed and failed.

property.name: WSARewriteReplyTo
property.display: Rewrite WS Addressing Reply To Header
property.summary: Rewrite WS Addressing Reply To Header

description.p: Identifies the URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the contents of the WS-Addressing ReplyTo header of the SOAP request, if present.

Use this property to modify the contents of an incoming WS-Addrssing ReplyTo SOAP header that identifies the recipient endpoint of response messages. This typically will be used to change the ReplyTo address to one that will send the response to this Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy.
This property is relevant when the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous, or Pure WS-Addressing.

Use the values-list to select the URL Rewrite Policy used to manipulate the contents of the original ReplyTo header. You can use the + and ... buttons to create a new URL Rewrite Policy or to modify an existing policy.

property.name: WSARewriteFaultTo
property.display: Rewrite WS Addressing Fault To Header
property.summary: Rewrite WS Addressing Fault To Header

description.p: Identifies the URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the contents of the WS-Addressing FaultTo header of the SOAP request, if present.

You can use this property to modify the contents of an incoming WS-Addressing FaultTo SOAP header that identifies the recipient endpoint of fault messages. This typically will be used to change the FaultTo address to one that will send the response to this Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy.
This property is relevant when the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous, or Pure WS-Addressing.

Use the values-list to select the URL Rewrite Policy used to manipulate the contents of the original FaultTo header. You can use the + and ... buttons to create a new URL Rewrite Policy or to modify an existing policy.
Identifies the URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the contents of the WS-Addressing To header of the SOAP request, if present.

You can use this property to modify the contents of an incoming WS-Addressing To SOAP header that identifies the message destination. If dynamic routing is not in use, this will typically be used to change the To header from an address that matches the front side of this Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy to one that addresses the back-side server.
If the To header does not match any of the rewrite rules, and the Gateway Type is not dynamic-backend, the To will be based on the backend URL.
This property is relevant when the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous, or Pure WS-Addressing.

Use the values-list to select the URL Rewrite Policy used to manipulate the contents of the original To header. You can use the + and ... buttons to create a new URL Rewrite Policy or to modify an existing policy.

property.name: WSAStrip
property.summary: Remove incoming WSA headers before forwarding

description.p: Contol whether to remove WS-Addressing headers when sending a request or response without using WS-Addressing.
When on (the default setting), the WS-Addressing headers (To, From, ReplyTo, FaultTo, Action, MessageID, and RelatesTo) will be stripped when sending synchronously.
When off, the WS-Addressing headers will not be removed.
This property is relevant when the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous, or Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing.
If the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous and this is on, WS-Addressing headers are stripped from incoming client SOAP requests before they are sent to the server.
If the WSA Mode is Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing and this is on, WS-Addressing headers are stripped from incoming server SOAP responses before they are sent to the client.
Provides a default value of the WS-Addressing ReplyTo SOAP header in request messages when Force Incoming WS-Addressing is enabled.

Because the WS-Addressing specifications do not require the inclusion of the ReplyTo header, the Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy may receive WS-Addressing messages that do not contain a ReplyTo header, or that contain the header with no value.
If the SOAP request has no WS-Addressing ReplyTo , or From SOAP header, this will provide a default value of the ReplyTo header. That header identifies the recipient endpoint of the response message.
When this happens, the Gateway will modify the Web Service Addressing message to include a ReplyTo header that contains the URL value specified by this property.
If a default recipient endpoint of response messages is not explicitly identified by this command, the default value is:
This property is relevant when the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous or Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing, and Force Incoming WS-Addressing is enabled.
Provides a default value of the WS-Addressing FaultTo SOAP header in request messages.

Because the WS-Addressing specifications do not require the inclusion of the FaultTo header, the Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy may receive WS-Addressing requests that do not contain a FaultTo SOAP header, or that contain the header with no value.

If the SOAP request has no WS-Addressing FaultTo , ReplyTo , or From SOAP header, this will provide a default value of the FaultTo header. That header identifies the recipient endpoint of an error message.
If a default recipient endpoint of fault messages is not explicitly identified by this command, the default value is:
This property is relevant when the WS-AddressingMode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous, or Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing.
Forces the insertion of WS-Addressing headers into traditionally addressed SOAP requests.
The Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy generally handles a mix of Web Service addressed and traditionally addressed messages. You can use this property to ensure that all messages use WS-Addressing.

When enabled (on), the Gateway converts traditionally addressed messages to WS-Addressing format through the addition of To , ReplyTo , FaultTo and MessageID WS-Addressing headers to the traditionally addressed message.
The ReplyTo header will be that configured in the Default WS-Addressing Reply-To property. The FaultTo header will be that configured in the Default WS-Addressing Fault-To property.
When disabled (off, the default), there is no insertion of WS-Addressing headers into traditionally addressed messages.
This property is relevant when the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous, or Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing.
Select the message exchange model between the DataPower service and a target server that uses WS-Addressing. The default is Synchronous.
This property is relevant when the WS-Addressing Mode is Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing or Pure WS-Addressing.
Specifies the HTTP Response Code sent to a client device prior to transmitting the actual asynchronous server response.

If the server response to an HTTP client request is asynchronous, the Multi-Protocol Gateway must close the original HTTP client channel with a valid response code. After the channel is closed, the Multi-Protocol Gateway forwards the server-generated response or fault message to the client over a new channel.

Provide an integer (within the range 200 through 599, with a default value of 204) that specifies the HTTP response code used to close the original client channel. While 204 is the default, 202 is more commonly required by current standards.
This property is relevant when the WSA Addressing Mode is either Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing , or Pure WS-Addressing .
Specifies the Front Side Protocol Handler that receives asynchronous server responses.

Use this property to specify the Front Side Protocol Handler that will receive the asynchronous server response, and then forward the response to the original client. This must be one of the Front Side Protocol Handlers that this gateway is already configured to listen on.

Note the Front Side Protocol Handler specified by this property can be programatically over-ridden by the var://context/__WSA_REQUEST/replyto variable, which will change the WS-Addressing ReplyTo header on the request to the server.
This property is relevant when the WSA Addressing Mode is either Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing , or Pure WS-Addressing AND the WS-Addressing Message Generation Pattern is Asynchronous .
Select a Front Side Protocol Handler from the values-list or use the + or … buttons to create a new Front Side Protocol handler or modify an existing one.
Specifies the asynchronous timeout value.
Sets the maximum period of time to wait for an asynchronous response from the server, before abandoning the transaction with an error.
Enter an integer (between the range 1 through 4000000, with a default of 120) that specifies the maximum wait period in seconds.
The timer value specified by this property can be programatically over-ridden by the var://service/wsa/timeout variable.

The establishemnt of this timer can be programatically over-ridden by the var://service/soap-oneway-mep variable, which elimates waiting for a response. This can be applied to messages known to use the SOAP 1.2 One-Way Message Exchange Pattern.
This property is relevant when the WSA Addressing Mode is either Synchronous Gatewayed to WS-Addressing , or Pure WS-Addressing AND the WS-Addressing Message Generation Pattern is Asynchronous .

property.name: WSRMEnabled
property.summary: Enable Web Services Reliable Messaging Mode
property.description: Enable the Web Services Reliable Messaging feature (WS-ReliableMessaging 1.1). WS-RM requires SOAP messages. The default is No WS-ReliableMessaging.

property.name: WSRMSequenceExpiration
property.summary: Set target sequence expiration interval for RM Destination and RM Source

description.p: Set the target expiration interval for all WS-RM Sequences. If an incoming CreateSequence SOAP message has an Expires interval longer than this configured value, it will be reduced to this value in the SequenceResponse SOAP message. The same applies to the Expires interval in any accepted Offer in an incomong CreateSequence. This is also used for the requested Expires value in any CreateSequence SOAP call made to the client or server from a RM Source.
This implementation will never request or accept a non-expiring sequence (the value "PT0S", representing zero seconds).
This property is relevant only when WS-RM is enabled.

property.name: WSRMAAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA policy for validating WS-RM control messages

description.p: Selects the AAA Policy to perform authentication of incoming WS-RM messages. While this is focused on protecting the WS-RM control SOAP messages, such as CreateSequence and TerminateSequence, it is also run on incoming WS-RM data messages with a Sequence header. This prevents unauthorized clients from using system resources by issuing CreateSequence requests, or from disrupting existing WS-RM sequences using CloseSequence or TerminateSequence messages, or from falsely acknowleding messages using SequenceAcknowledgement messages. This would normally be the same AAA Policy used in later processing by the request or response rules, the results are cached so it is not evaluated again.
Note that this also applies to a CreateSequence request received from the server. If the server is not providing this authentication information, configure to have the WS-RM Source make offers.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM is enabled.
To create a new AAA Policy, click the + button. To edit an AAA Policy, click the … button.

property.name: WSRMDestinationAcceptCreateSequence
property.summary: Enable creation of RM Destinations on this Gateway by incoming CreateSequence requests

description.p: Accept incoming WS-RM CreateSequence SOAP request, and create an RM Destination when one is recieved. If this is enabled, both the client and the server can use WS-RM to send messages to this gateway. If this is disabled, the client cannot use WS-RM to communicate with this gateway. If this is disabled, the only way that an RM Destination can be created on this gateway is if the RM Source has been configured to make offers, in which case an Offer and Accept can create an RM Destination for the server to send WS-RM messages to.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM is enabled.

property.name: WSRMDestinationMaximumSequences
property.summary: Set maximum simultaneous active Sequences to RM Destinations on this Gateway

description.p: Set a limit on the maximum number of RM Destinations that may be created on this Gateway by CreateSequence SOAP requests. Attempts by clients to create sequences in excess of this limit will result in a SOAP Fault. This controls memory resource utilization.
This limit does not apply to RM Destinations created by peer acceptance of offers made in CreateSequence SOAP requests sent by this Gateway.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM and Destination Accept Incoming CreateSequence are enabled.

property.name: WSRMDestinationInOrder
property.summary: Enable the InOrder Delivery Assurance for RM Destinations

description.p: Enable the InOrder Delivery Assurance for RM Destinations, in addition to the standard ExactlyOnce DeliveryAssurance. No messages will be passed from the receive queue for further processing unless their sequence number assigned by the client is one greater than the last one processed.
InOrder Delivery Assurance considerably increases memory and resource use by the RM Destination.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM is enabled, and Destination Accept Incoming CreateSequence or Source Make Two-Way Offer are enabled.

property.name: WSRMDestinationMaximumInOrderQueueLength
property.summary: Set maximum RM Destination queue length for InOrder Delivery Assurance
property.description: Sets the maximum length of a RM Destination queue when Destination InOrder Delivery Service is enabled. This is the maximum number of messages held in the queue beyond a gap in the received sequence numbers. This controls memory use.

property.name: WSRMDestinationAcceptOffers
property.summary: Enable accepting Offers in received CreateSequence

description.p: Accept offers for two-way WS-RM contained in CreateSequence SOAP request. If an offer is included, the creation of an RM Destination will also result in the creation of an RM Source to reliably send responses to the client.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM and Destination Accept Incoming CreateSequence are enabled.

property.name: WSRMFrontForce
property.summary: Require WS-ReliableMessaging to be used on SOAP messages processed by the request rules

description.p: Require the use of WS-ReliableMessaging for all SOAP messages being processed by the request rules. The client must establish a sequence using CreateSequence SOAP call, and must include a Sequence in each SOAP header. Any SOAP request messages without a Sequence header will result in a SOAP fault.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM and Destination Accept Incoming CreateSequence are enabled.

property.name: WSRMBackForce
property.summary: Require WS-ReliableMessaging to be used on SOAP messages processed by the response rules

description.p: Require the use of WS-ReliableMessaging for all SOAP messages being processed by the response rules. Any SOAP response messages without a Sequence header will result in a SOAP fault.

Note that when WS-Addressing is in use, SOAP messages without a WS-Addressing RelatesTo SOAP Header will be processed by the request rule, not the response rule, even if they come from the back-side server.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM is enabled, and Destination Accept Incoming CreateSequence or Source Make Two-Way Offer are enabled.

property.name: WSRMBackCreateSequence
property.summary: Create an RM Source for requests to server

description.p: Create an RM Source from the back side to the server, by sending a CreateSequence SOAP request to the server address, when there is SOAP data to sent to the server, and there is no RM Source that was created by a MakeOffer from the server.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM is enabled.

property.name: WSRMFrontCreateSequence
property.summary: Create an RM Source for responses to client

description.p: Create an RM Source from the front side to the client, by sending a CreateSequence SOAP request to the WS-Addressing ReplyTo address, when there is SOAP data to sent to the client, and there is no RM Source that was created by a MakeOffer from the client.
To create this two-way WS-RM connection, WS-Addressing must be in use on the front side.
This property is relevant only when WS-RM is enabled, and the WS-Addressing Mode is WS-Addressing Gatewayed to Synchronous , or Pure WS-Addressing .

property.name: WSRMSourceMakeOffer
property.summary: Include offer for Two-Way WS-RM in CreateSequence

description.p: Include an Offer for two-way WS-RM in CreateSequence SOAP requests made to the server as a result of request processing. This may result in creating an RM Destination for the server to send responses on when the gateway creates an RM Source to send requests to the server.
If the server does not Accept the Offer, no RM Destination will be created.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging and Source Create Sequence on Response are enabled.

property.name: WSRMUsesSequenceSSL
property.summary: Use SSL/TLS to protect sequence integrity

description.p: Use the WS-ReliableMessaging SSL/TLS security model for protecting the integrity and security of messages sent from RM Sources for this gateway. This provides confidentiality (through SSL/TLS), and protects the WS-RM state from alteration by unauthorized parties.

Outgoing CreateSequence control messages will have the UsesSequenceSSL SOAP header block. This will tell the peer RM Destination that all control and data messages for this conversation must use the same SSL/TLS session. Any message to that RM Destination Identifier that is not associated with the same SSL/TLS session will be rejected.
The lifetime of a SSL/TLS protected Sequence will be limited by the lifetime of the SSL/TLS session that is used to protect that Sequence.
Acceptance and enforcement of UsesSequenceSSL on incoming WS-RM connections to RM Destinations is automatic if SSL is enabled.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

Selects a particular front-side protocol handler to request to receive asynchronous acknowledgements and control messages responses on the front side of the gateway. If not configured, they will be requested to be received at the URL of the original request message that causes the creation of the RM Source.

The front-side protocol handler must be one that is already configured as one of the active ones for this Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy. It can be the one that incoming front side requests are arriving on, or can be any other one that the client WS-RM implementation can reach.
An URL will be generated from the base URL of the protocol handler, which may also have a path added due to the WSDL describing the service.

This generated URL is used as the value of CreateSequence/AcksTo when sending a Create Sequence SOAP request, it is used as the CreateSequenceResponse/Accept/AcksTo when accepting an offer from the client. This generated URL is also used as the WS-Addressing ReplyTo address for WS-RM control SOAP messages (CreateSequence, CloseSequence, and TerminateSequence) sent by the RM Source to the client.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Response or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.
Select a Front Side Protocol Handler from the values-list or use the + or … buttons to create a new Front Side Protocol handler or modify an existing one.

Selects a particular front-side protocol handler to receive asynchronous WS-RM SequenceAcknowledgement messages. If this is not configured, but there is a WS-Addressing Reply Point configured, it will be used to receive SequenceAcknowledgements. If neither is set, the back side RM Source will expect synchronous SequenceAcknowledgemnts in response messages.

The front-side protocol handler must be one that is already configured as one of the active ones for this Multi-Protocol Gateway or WS-Proxy. It can be the one that incoming front side requests are arriving on, or can be any other one that the server WS-RM implementation can reach.

When configured, the AcksTo field in WS-RM CreateSequence SOAP messages sent to the server will be the base URL of this front-side protocol handler. If this is not configured, but a WS-Addressing Reply Point is, the AcksTo field will come from that front side protocol handler.
If neither is configured, the AcksTo field will be "http://www.w3.org/2005/08/addressing/anonymous".
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.
Select a Front Side Protocol Handler from the values-list or use the + or … buttons to create a new Front Side Protocol handler or modify an existing one.

property.name: WSRMSourceMaximumSequences
property.summary: Set maximum simultaneous active Sequences from RM Sources on this Gateway

description.p: Set a limit on the maximum number of simultaneously active Sequences from RM Sources of this Gateway. Each remote RM Destination Endpoint Reference (URL) requires one sequence. This controls memory resource utilization.
Transactions requiring to creating sequences in excess of this limit will result in a SOAP Fault.
Incoming CreateSequence SOAP requests with an Offer will have the offer ignored if accepting the offer would exceed this limit.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

property.name: WSRMSourceRetransmissionInterval
property.summary: How long RM Source waits for Ack before message retransmission

description.p: How long a RM Source will wait for an Ack before retransmitting the message. This also applies to the retransmission of a CreateSequence, CloseSequence, or TerminateSequence SOAP requests. If Front Exponential Backoff is enabled, this is the initial timeout.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

property.name: WSRMSourceExponentialBackoff
property.summary: Whether RM Source uses exponential backoff for retransmission

description.p: Controls whether exponential backoff is used to increase the interval between subsequent retransmissions on unacknowledged messages by a RM Source.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

property.name: WSRMSourceMaximumRetransmissions
property.summary: How many times a RM Source will retransmit a message before declaring a failure

description.p: How many times a RM Source will retransmit a message before declaring a failure. This also controls retransmission of CreateSequence, CloseSequence, and TerminateSequence SOAP requests.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

property.name: WSRMSourceMaximumQueueLength
property.summary: How many messages a RM Source will hold waiting for Acks

description.p: Maximum length of a RM Source queue for responses. This is the maximum number of messages held in the queue awaiting Ack messages. This controls memory use.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

property.name: WSRMSourceRequestAckCount
property.summary: Set how many messages sent by a RM Source before requesting Ack

description.p: How many messages the a RM Source will send before including the AckRequested SOAP header to request an acknowledgement. The AckRequested SOAP header is always included when a message is retransmitted.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

property.name: WSRMSourceInactivityClose
property.summary: How long a RM Source waits for more messages before closing sequence

description.p: How long the a RM Source will wait for an another message to be sent before closing the sequence by sending a CloseSequence or TerminateSequence SOAP message.
CloseSequence is sent when the inactivity timer expires if there are oustanding unacknowledged messages, otherwise Terminate sequence is sent.
This property is relevant only when WS-ReliableMessaging is enabled, and Source Create Sequence on Request, Source Create Sequence on Response, or Destination Accept Two-Way Offers are enabled.

property.name: StylePolicy
property.description: Select a Document Processing Policy from the list of available policies. Click + to create a new Policy. This policy controls the transformations, filtering and other actions taken on the submitted message.

property.name: Type
property.description: Specify the mode of the Gateway. The default is Static Backend.

property-group.name: Probe
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional probe settings
property-group.description:
The MultiStep Probe allows developers to view the changing value of variables and the changing contents of processing contexts. The developer can step through each action for any given transaction, up to a configured number of transactions. The Probe Settings page turns on this debugging tool and also sets the number of concurrently captured transactions.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

description.p: A Multi-Protocol Gateway service can accept client-originated messages in a variety of protocols. The gateway can subsequently pass messages to a back end server using a variety of protocols. The protocol used on the client side need not be the same as that on the back side.

A Gateway can support more than one client, or Front Side, protocol. Similarly, the Gateway can support more than one back side, or server protocol. The messages may be processed and routed using any of the standard Document Processing Actions available to a firewall or a proxy.

property.name: Type
property.description: Select the mode of operation for the Web Service Proxy. The default is Static from WSDL.

property.name: AutoCreateSources
property.description: The front side ports that accept connections must have configured Front Side Protocol Source Handlers. If no Front Side Protocol Handler is configured and auto-create is enabled, a default Protocol Handler will be created. Currently only auto-creates HTTP sources.

description.p: An Endpoint Rewrite Policy determines the URL that clients use to send requests for the services described in the WSDL file(s); the URL published to directory services (such as UDDI); and can also determine the URL of the back end application services.

This policy allows you to define service endpoint URLs for more than one local interface. You can define the URLs published to directory services, which may be different than the locally defined interface when load balancers are used. You can override the URLS defined in the WSDL files for the Web Services endpoints, redefining these URLS to a different location. This is useful for maintenance windows.
A configured Endpoint Rewrite Policy takes precedence over any Local Endpoint Rewrite and Remote Endpoint Rewrite policies.

property.name: LocalEndpointRewrite
property.summary: URL rewrite policy to rewrite the wsdl:port address

description.p: Specify a URL Rewrite Policy used to modify the wsdl:port address specified in the source WSDL when the service is loaded. If no URL Rewrite Policy is specified, the default local address is the IP address of the device and the relative URI and the original port number from the wsdl:port address used in the source WSDL.

For example, the WSDL may specify *:2100/search/find and this URL Rewrite Policy might rewrite it to *:2100/searchsvc/find . Client requests to the web service would be rewritten to http://dpdeviceaddr:2100/searchsvc/find .

property.name: RemoteEndpointRewrite
property.summary: URL Rewrite Policy to rewrite the remote wsdl:port address

description.p: Specify a URL Rewrite Policy used to modify the wsdl:port address specified in the source WSDL when the service is loaded. If no URL Rewrite Policy is specified, the default remote address is exactly the same wsdl:port address used in the source WSDL.
For example, the WSDL may specify http://api.beagle.com:2100/search/find" and this URL Rewrite Policy might rewrite it to http://192.168.2.21:2000/search/find" .

A single Authorization and Authentication policy may be applied to all messages handled by this proxy service. Unlike a Style Policy, this policy employs no selective matching rules; all messages are processed by this policy.
Select an existing AAA Policy from the list or click the + button to create a new policy.

The service can apply a user-defined processing policy to messages processed by the service. This policy may take a wide range of action on messages. Matching rules select messages for particular processing actions, as with a firewall or proxy service. This policy takes effect in addition to the processing applied automatically by the service.
Select an existing policy from the list or click the + button to create a new policy.

Note that this is a Web Service Processing Policy. A Web Service Processing Policy works only with a Web Service Proxy and not with any other service on the device. You also cannot use an existing XML Firewall or Multi-Protocol Gateway Processing Policy with a Web Service Proxy.

property.name: RemoteFetchRetry
property.summary: Policy for controlling how a remote WSDL should be fetched.

property.name: WSDLCachePolicy
property.description: A WSDL that is part of the cache policy is refreshed when its TTL to is reached. Refresh retrieves the WSDL from the source location and refreshes the web service proxy state. Depending upon the changes in the WSDL file itself, the Proxy may reconfigure itself in any number of ways, including adding new endpoints or removing existing endpoints.

property.name: BaseWSDL
property.description: A proxy may use one or more WSDL files to define the service the proxy handles. Those WSDL files are defined on this page.

description.p: Each WSDL Operation of the web service proxied by a Web Service Proxy can have a user policy defined for that component.

Components are specified by the combination of Target Namespace, WSDL file, Service, PortType, Binding and Operation. For example, to specify all operations in the target namespace MySvc, enter "MySvc" in the Target Namespace field and set all other inputs to *. To specify only one particular operation, named GetLottoPick for example, enter "wsdl:definitions//wsdl:operation/@GetLottoPick" in the Operations field and set all others to *.

The policy applied to the specified component consists of six options: Enable, Publish, Validate Faults, Validate Headers, Validate Requests and Validate Responses. See below for more information about policy options.

property.name: ClientPrincipal
property.summary: Full name of Kerberos client principal
property.description: Specify the full name of the client principal when the Web Services Proxy needs to decrypt automatically encrypted requests. Use this property when the encryption uses a Kerberos session key or uses a key that was derived from the session key.

property.name: ServerPrincipal
property.summary: Full name of Kerberos server principal
property.description: Specify the full name of the server principal when the Web Services Proxy needs to decrypt automatically encrypted requests. Use this property when the encryption uses a Kerberos session key or uses a key that was derived from the session key.

property.name: KerberosKeytab
property.description: Select the Kerberos keytab file that contains the principals that the Web Services Proxy uses to decrypt automatically encrypted requests and responses.

property.name: DecryptKey
property.summary: Crypto key that decrypts encrypted operations
property.description: The ws-proxy will automatically decrypt encrypted requests. Configure the decrypt key to explicitely select the private key used in the decryption.

property.name: SOAPActionPolicy
property.description: Select how to handle the SOAPAction HTTP header.

property.name: UDDISubscriptions
property.summary: Obtain web services via a UDDI subscription
property.description: The ws-proxy will load and proxy services obtained via these subscriptions.

property.name: WSRRSubscriptions
property.summary: Obtain web services via a WSRR subscription
property.description: The ws-proxy will load and proxy services obtained via these subscriptions.

property.name: OperationPriority
property.summary: Control the scheduling priority and resource allocation for a specified webservice operation
property.description: Operation Priority

property.name: OperationConformancePolicy
property.summary: Configuration of conformance checking of received messages for a specified webservice operation
property.description: Operation Conformance Policy

property.name: OperationPolicySubjectOptOut
property.summary: Configuration to ignore one or more policy subjects for a webservice operation
property.description: Operation Policy Subject Opt Out

property.name: PolicyParameter
property.summary: Controls the assignment of policy parameters to wsdls
property.description: Policy Parameters

property.name: ReliableMessaging
property.summary: Control reliable messaging properties for a specified webservice operation
property.description: Reliable Messaging

property-group.name: Probe
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional probe settings
property-group.description:
The MultiStep Probe allows developers to view the changing value of variables and the changing contents of processing contexts. The developer can step through each action for any given transaction, up to a configured number of transactions. The Probe Settings page turns on this debugging tool and also sets the number of concurrently captured transactions.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

description.p: A Web Service Proxy virtualizes application services described by WSDL files. The Proxy provides alternate endpoint URLs, message validation, service level monitoring and automatic updating when provided with only one or more WSDL files.

In addition, a Web Service Proxy can provide the full range of processing services available to an XML Firewall or Multi-Protocol Gateway, such as Authentication and Authorization, cryptographic operations, transformations and dynamic routing, and more.

object.name: HTTPInputConversionMap

property.name: DefaultInputEncoding
property.summary: The default Encoding that each value is assumed to have.
property.description: Select the default encoding to use for any name-value pair in an HTTP form where the name does not match any of the patterns in the Encoding Map.

property.name: InputEncoding
property.summary: A map from HTTP form name patterns to Encoding rule.
property.description: This allows selecting the Encoding for values based on their name. The names are matched by PCREs. Each PCRE is associated with an Encoding that controls how the value is mapped to the contents of an <arg> element in the resulting XML. This is an ordered list, comparision of the name proceeds until the first match. If there is no match, the Encoding will be selected by the Default Encoding of this HTTP Input Conversion Map.

object.summary: Input Conversion Map for HTTP Forms.
object.description: This defines the rules for handling HTTP to XML conversion of form values in an HTTP GET or POST of a form. There are different conversion (Encoding) rules for the values. They control how the value is mapped to the contents of its <arg> element in the resulting XML. There is a default Encoding, which is all that is required. There can also be specific Encodings applied to values based on the name associated with a value, which is done using an ordered list of PCREs.

property.name: Identifier
property.description: An optional string that specifies the contents of the User-Agent request-header field. By default, a User Agent request-header field is not transmitted.

property.name: MaxRedirects
property.description: An integer (within the range 0 through 128, with a default of 8) that specifies the maximum number of HTTP redirect messages received before the target URL is declared unreachable.

property.name: Timeout
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 86400, with a default of 300) that specifies the maximum amount of idle time on an established connection before the connection is aborted.

property.name: ProxyPolicies
property.description: Configure a proxy policy that associates a set of URLs with a specific HTTP proxy

property.name: SSLPolicies
property.description: Configure a proxy policy that associates a set of URLs with a specific SSL Proxy Profile. Whenever the Agent is given a URL that matches the set defined, it will use the corresponding SSL Proxy Profile for SSL communications with the resource.

property.name: BasicAuthPolicies
property.description: Configure a proxy policy that associates a set of URLs with a specific username and password for Basic-Auth authentication.

property.name: SoapActionPolicies
property.description: Configure a policy that associates a set of URLs with a specific Soap-Action HTTP header

property.name: PubkeyAuthPolicies
property.description: Configure a proxy policy that associates a set of URLs with a specific private key for Pubkey authentication. Note that this setting defines the private key used in Pubkey authentication; the remote host to which the Agent is connecting must possess and reference the corresponding certificate in order to successfully communicate.

property.name: AllowCompressionPolicies
property.description: The User Agent will compress messages that are sent to URLs that match the URL Matching Expression.

property.name: Restrict10Policies
property.description: Associate a set of URLs with a specific policy limiting http request versions to 1.0. This policy is cumulative - if any transaction, url match, or gateway should have a restrictive policy, that transaction will be carried out at HTTP/1.0.

property.name: AddHeaderPolicies
property.description: Configure one or more URL Match Expresssions and corresponding Header Injection Policies. If the URL matches the expression, the corresponding HTTP Header is injected into the message.

property.name: UploadChunkedPolicies
property.description: When the device employs the HTTP/1.1 protocol, the body of the document can be delimited by either Content-Length or chunked encodings. While all servers will understand how to interpret Content-Length, many applications will fail to understand Chunked encoding. For this reason, Content-Length is the standard method used. However doing so interferes with the ability of the device to fully stream. To stream full documents towards the back end server, this property should be turned on. However, the back end server must be RFC 2616 compatible, because this feature cannot be renegotiated at run time, unlike all other HTTP/1.1 features which can be negotiated down at runtime if necessary.

property.name: FTPPolicies
property.description: Associate a set of FTP URLs with a specific policy controlling the default values of many FTP client options for outgoing FTP connections. These override the compiled in defaults, and can be further overridden by query parameters in the URL used to initiate the file transfer.

description.p: Use this page to configure a User Agent, which the device uses to retrieve resources (for example, stylesheets or XML documents) from remote servers.
A User Agent can also affect the messages emitted by a Multi-Protocol Gateway

property.name: URL
property.description: Enter the URL of the import package. The import tool does not support SCP and SFTP URL protocols. All other URL protocols are available; for example, HTTP, HTTPS, or FTP.

property.name: ImportFormat
property.description: Select the format of the package.

property.name: OverwriteFiles
property.description: When checked on, any files in the package will overwrite any files of the same path and name that already exist on the device.

property.name: OverwriteObjects
property.description: When checked on, any objects in the package will overwrite any objects of the same class and name that already exist on the device.

property.name: DestinationDomain
property.description: Select a domain from the list of domains that exist on the device. The import package will be imported into the selected domain, regardless of any domain indicated in the package configurationm files.

property.name: DeploymentPolicy
property.description: Select a deployment policy from the list of configuration deployment policies. The configuration contained in the import package will be preprocessed according to the policy prior to being imported.

property.name: LocalIPRewrite
property.summary: Rewrite the local IP on import.
property.description: When set to 'on' the local-ip addresses contained in the import-package are rewritten to match the local configuration when imported. In other words, a service bound to eth1 on the device exporting the configuration will be rewritten to bind to eth1 on the local device the configuration is imported in.

property.name: OnStartup
property.description: When set to 'on' the import-package is imported at startup. The configuration will be marked external and cannot be saved locally. It is equivalent to 'import-always'. When set to 'off' executing the import has to be triggered manually and the configuration will not be marked external and can be saved locally. It is equivalent to 'import-once'.

description.p: Import Package allows the system to import a configuration package from an external server, such as a centralized configuration server, when the configuration of the DataPower system is reloaded (such as during a reboot). This package can optionally overwrite existing files or objects.
An import package object specifies a source, content type and import parameters for a single import bundle.

object.name: IMSConnect

property.name: HostName
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the IMS Connect server.

property.name: Port
property.description: Specify the port on which the IMS Connect server is running.

property.name: UserName
property.summary: Host security ID to use for connecting to the IMS Connect
property.description: The plaintext string sent to the server for identifying the client.

property.name: Password
property.description: The host security password used to login to the IMS Connect server. Enter the password twice to confirm its accuracy.

property.name: TranCode
property.description: The IMS transaction code to invoke.

property.name: Group
property.description: The group the Host security ID belongs to.

property.name: Datastore
property.summary: Data Store of the IMS Server
property.description: It specifies the Datastore name (IMS destination ID).

property.name: ClientID
property.description: A string of 1 to 8 uppercase alphanumeric (A through Z, 0 to 9) or special (@, #, $) characters, left justified, and padded with blanks. It specifies the name of the client ID that is used by IMS Connect. If this string is not supplied from the client, then the user exit will generate it.

property.name: LtermName
property.description: LTERM override value to be used by OTMA.

property.name: Exit
property.summary: Exit Program to use for all the IMS connections. *SAMPLE* will be used if not supplied.
property.description: Exit Program to use for all the IMS connections

property.name: EBCDICConversion
property.description: This option can be turned on for converting the headers to EBCDIC. The IMS Connect exit should be able to process EBCDIC data. Some IMS Connect exits can handle both UTF-8 and EBCDIC. This conversion affects only the headers. Any data conversion should be done in the policy using transformation.

property.name: EncodingScheme
property.description: Select the Unicode encoding schema. Leave as (none) to be set dynamically in the IMS header. (For example, in the IMS proxy scenario, incoming IMS header value could be used directly.)

property.name: IRMTimer
property.description: Set the IRM_TIMER value to an appropriate wait time for IMS to return data to IMS Connect. See IMS Connect documentation for details. An example value of 21 would set an IRM Timer value of 0.21 sec.

property.name: GenerateClientIDPrefix
property.description: Two letter prefix for generated client ID. "DP" will be used if not specified

object.description: Configuration object that holds IMS Connect properties. All the properties in the Advanced tab are default values. Some of them can be over-ridden in the URL and others through header injection.

object.name: IncludeConfig

property.name: URL
property.description: Enter the URL of the configuration file to include. The URL should take the form 'protocol://username:password@host/path' if a username and password is required to retrieve the file.

property.name: OnStartup
property.description: When set to 'on' the configuration is executed at startup. The configuration will be marked external and cannot be saved locally. It is equivalent to 'include-always'. When set to 'off' executing the configuration has to be executed manually. The configuration will not be marked external and can be saved locally. It is equivalent to 'include-once'.

property.name: InterfaceDetection
property.description: This setting only affects the execution of configuration files from remote servers. If set to 'on' the remote file is executed asynchronously. It will be executed after the associated IP interface is operational.

object.description: Allows the inclusion of external configuration files during startup. The included configuration files may reside on the local device or on a remote host.

object.name: IPInterface

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: Primary IP address and address mask

property.name: UseDHCP
property.description: Select on to enable the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP); select off to disable DHCP (the default state).

property.name: DefaultGateway
property.summary: IP address of the default gateway

property.name: SecondaryAddress
property.summary: Additional IP addresses assigned to this interface

property.name: UseARP
property.description: Select on to enable the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP); select off to disable ARP. By default, ARP is enabled.

object.name: EthernetInterface

property.name: MTU
property.description: The maximum size of the MAC layer data field that may be handled on this interface. Increasing this over 1500 bytes should only be done if it is known that all other interfaces on this network have been similarly configured. An extra 4 bytes is added automatically if any VLAN Sub-Interfaces are enabled on this interface.

property.name: MACAddress
property.description: Provide a 48-bit hexadecimal MAC address assigned to this interface, overriding the default one assigned when the system was manufactured. Must be a unicast address (first byte must be even).

property.name: Mode
property.description: Select the interface speed and direction of the Ethernet unshielded twisted pair physical (PHY) layer. Because some networking equipment might not negotiate properly, this property allows you to explicitly set speed and direction.

property.name: StandbyControls
property.description: Defines the standby control that this interface is a part of. A standby control defines a group of interfaces on one broadcast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. If at least one member of a standby group can reach the broadcast domain, then it will be receiving traffic for the virtual IP address of that standby group. The broadcast domain is actually defined by the group of interfaces that can receive traffic on the IP multicast address 224.0.0.2 (All Routers) from each other. If the broadcast domain is partitioned, then there will be an active interface listening on the virtual IP address in each partition. There is a restriction that a given physical interface on the system can be in at most one standby group. Note that the only event controlling whether an interface will vie to be the active member of the group is that the interface is up. Only one interface (Ethernet or VLAN) on a given physical Ethernet interface may have standby configured.

object.description: Configure/Manage Ethernet Interfaces

object.name: VLANInterface

property.name: Interface
property.description: The Ethernet interface that this VLAN Sub-Interface is hosted on. This will enable that Ethernet interface, even if the Ethernet interface has not been configured with an IP address.

property.name: Identifier
property.description: Select the decimal number of the VLAN Identifier to associate with this VLAN Sub-Interface. Must be unique among all VLANs on one Ethernet interface. Note that VLAN Identifier 1 is generally reserved internally by switches for untagged packets, so it probably should not be used.

property.name: DefaultOutboundPriority
property.description: Select the priority value to insert in outgoing VLAN headers for packets sent on this VLAN Sub-Interface. This goes in the user_control field of the Tag Control Information.

property.name: StandbyControls
property.description: Defines the standby control that this interface is a part of. A standby control defines a group of interfaces on one broadcast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. If at least one member of a standby group can reach the broadcast domain, then it will be receiving traffic for the virtual IP address of that standby group. The broadcast domain is actually defined by the group of interfaces that can receive traffic on the IP multicast address 224.0.0.2 (All Routers) from each other. If the broadcast domain is partitioned, then there will be an active interface listening on the virtual IP address in each partition. There is a restriction that a given physical interface on the system can be in at most one standby group. Note that the only event controlling whether an interface will vie to be the active member of the group is that the interface is up. Only one interface (Ethernet or VLAN) on a given physical Ethernet interface may have standby configured.

object.description: Configure/Manage VLAN Sub-Interfaces
Configure network Ethernet interfaces

object.name: IScsiChapConfig

property.name: Username
property.description: Specify the user name for the CHAP.

property.name: Password
property.description: Specify the password for the user for the CHAP.

object.description: The configuration of the Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP) for iSCSI targets.

object.name: IScsiHBAConfig

description.p:
Specify a valid iSCSI Name for this HBA instance. The name can be between 1 and 244 characters in length. Sample formats of an ISCSI qualified name (IQN), based on IETF RFC 3720, are:
iqn.2001-04.com.example
iqn.2001-04.com.example:storage.disk2.sys1.xyz

property.name: UseDHCP
property.description: Set whether to use Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). When set to "on", enables DHCP. When set to "off", the default value, disables DHCP.

property.name: IpAddress
property.description: Specify the IP address for this HBA instance.

property.name: DefaultGateway
property.description: Specify the IP address of the default gateway for this HBA instance.

object.description: The configuration of the iSCSI Host Bus Adapter (HBA). The iSCSI HBA is the hardware that is responsible for the management of iSCSI communications.

object.name: IScsiTargetConfig

property.name: TargetName
property.summary: iSCSI Name for a remote target
property.description: Specify a valid iSCSI Name assigned the iSCSI target. When changed, this value overrides the default value that was assigned when the system was manufactured. If changed, the name must be unique in the iSCSI environment and be between 1 and 224 characters in length.

property.name: IPAddress
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the remote iSCSI target.

property.name: PortNumber
property.description: Specify the IP port number to connect to the remote iSCSI target. If not specified, the value defaults to 3260.

property.name: HBARef
property.summary: HBA instance to which to bind
property.description: Select the HBA instance to which to bind this target instance.

property.name: CHAPRef
property.summary: CHAP entry to which to assign
property.description: Select the CHAP entry to which to assign this target instance.

object.description: Defines the configuration of the connection instance to a remote iSCSI target.

object.name: IScsiVolumeConfig

property.name: ReadOnly
property.summary: Allow only file reads on this iSCSI Volume.
property.description: Set the access permission to files on the storage volume. When set to "on", the access permission is read-only. When set to "off", the default value, the access permission is read-write.

property.name: Directory
property.description: Specify the subdirectory in the local: and logstore: directories where the files on the storage volume are available. Each application domain contains these subdirectories. These subdirectories are not shared across application domains. The name can be up to 64 characters long. The name cannot start with a period. The name can consist of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numeric digits, dashes, underscores, and periods.

property.name: LunValue
property.description: Specify the Logical Unit Number (LUN). Use an integer in the range of 0 through 255.

property.name: TargetRef
property.description: Select the iSCSI target instance to which to bind this iSCSI volume.

object.description: File system operations for iSCSI devices.

property.name: UserName
property.summary: Username to use for connecting to the server
property.description: Specifies the account name used to access the WebSphere or TIBCO Application Server.

property.name: Password
property.summary: Password to use for connecting to the server
property.description: Specifies the password used to access the WebSphere or TIBCO Application Server.

property.name: Transactional
property.summary: Acknowledges messages only if transaction was successful.

description.p: Enables (on) or disables (off) transaction-based processing in which messages are acknowledged only after the transaction has succeeded.
Transaction-based processing is disabled by default.

property.name: MemoryThreshold
property.summary: Maximum memory size allowed for pending messages

description.p: Specifies the maximum memory allocation for pending messages.
Enter an integer (within the range 1048576 through 1073741824) that specifies the maximum memory (in bytes) allocated for pending messages.
By default, the maximum memory allocation is set at 268,435,456 bytes.

property.name: MaximumMessageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of messages accepted from the JMS or TIBCO manager

description.p: Specifies the maximum message size supported by the WAS JMS or TIBCO EMS object.
Enter an integer (with the range 0 through 1073741824) that specifies the maximum message size in bytes.
By default, the maximum message size is set at 1048576 bytes.
You can use the special value, 0, to disable the enforcement of maximum message sizes.
Select the default message type. This property is used only when the message type cannot be determined from the message headers.
On the transaction level, the DP_JMSMessageType header can change this setting.
Specifies the maximum number of simultaneous open connections to the WebSphere Application or TIBCO Server.

Session requests in excess of the integer value set by the Maximum number of Sessions per Connection property trigger the establishment of a new connection to the WebSphere Application or TIBCO Server, assuming that the number of current connections is less than the value specified by this property.

For example, assuming default values (20 for sessions per connection, and 5 for connection limit), and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection.

property.name: SessionsPerConnection
property.display: Maximum number of Sessions per Connection
property.summary: Maximum number of sessions per connection

description.p: Specifies the maximum number of concurrent multiplexed sessions supported by a single connection to the WebSphere Application or TIBCO Server.

Session requests in excess of the integer value set by the The desirable number of sessions property trigger the establishment of a new connection to the WebSphere Application Server, assuming that the number of current connections is less than the value specified by this property.

For example, assuming default values (20 for sessions per connection, and 5 for connection limit), and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection.

property.name: AutoRetry
property.description: Enables (on, the default state) or disables (off) an automatic critical error-recovery procedure that attempts to re-establish a connection that has been broken in response to an error condition.

property.name: RetryInterval
property.summary: Seconds to wait before retrying failing connections.

description.p: If Automatic Retry is enabled (the default state), specifies the interval in seconds between connection re-establishment attempts.

property.name: SSLProfile
property.summary: SSL Profile. It is used to establish secure connection to JMS server

description.p: Identifies the SSL Proxy Profile used to establish a secure (SSL-enabled) connection to the WebSphere Application or TIBCO Server.
Use the values list to select an existing SSL Proxy Profile; use the + button to create a new profile, or the ... button to edit a current profile.
In the absence of an explicitly assigned SSL Proxy Profile, the firmware establishes a non-secure (no SSL support) connection to the WebSphere Application or TIBCO Server.
If you specify an SSL Proxy for connection to a WebSphere Application Server, the cipher suite associated with the proxy is replaced by an IBM default cipher suite (SSL_RSS_WITH_NULL_MD5).

property.name: EnableLogging
property.description: Enables (on) or disables (off, the default state) an expanded JMS logging facility.

object.name: TibcoEMSServer

description.p: Defines a series of servers for load-balancing, each with an optional backup servers for fault-tolerance. For load-balancing, select the algorithm from the Load Balancing Algorithm list on the Main tab.
Note: The definition of any server for load-balancing or fault-tolerance overrides the value of the TIBCO EMS Server Host property on the Main tab.
Specify the host name or IP address with the listening port of the server in the host : port format. Without the port specification, the default is port 7222.
Note: This property is a required property. However if this configuration defines load-balancing or fault-tolerance behavior on the Load Balancing/Fault-Tolerance tab, this property is ignored.

property.name: ConnectionClientID
property.description: Specify the string to set as the TIBCO EMS Connection Client identifier.

property.name: LoadBalancingAlgorithm
property.summary: Algorithm to balance the real servers.
property.description: Select the algorithm to use to balance the real servers.

object.description: TIBCO EMS Server is responsible for messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring/polling queues, by ensuring that sent messages are directed to the correct receive queue, or that messages are routed to another queue manager.

object.name: WebSphereJMSServer

description.p: Identifies the connection host, port, and protocol to use for the bootstrap process.

A service integration bus (SIB) supports applications using message-based and service-oriented architectures. A bus is a group of interconnected servers and clusters that have been added as members of the bus. Applications connect to a bus at one of the messaging engines associated with its bus members.
A messaging engine is a component, running inside a server, that manages messaging resources for a bus member. Applications are connected to a messaging engine when accessing a SIB.

Applications (such as the JMS object) running outside the WebSphere environment cannot locate directly a suitable messaging engine to connect to the target bus. In such cases the remote clients or servers must access the bus through a bootstrap server that is a member of the target bus. A bootstrap server is an application server running the SIB process, but need not be running any message engines. Rather the bootstrap server selects a messaging engine that is running in an application server that supports the bootstrap protocol requested by the remote device.

To connect to a messaging engine the remote application first connects to a bootstrap server. The bootstrap server selects a messaging engine and tells the client application to connect to that message engine to gain bus access.
A bootstrap server uses a host name or IP address, a port number, and a bootstrap transport chain (which identifies the protocol stack offered by the bootstrap server) to define an endpoint address.
The transport chain used for bootstrap access does not need to match the transport chain that is used for message exchange.
Identifies the predefined transport chain provided by the WebSphere Application Server, and used for message exchange between the application server and the WAS JMS object.
This property takes one of the following values.
(the default) specifies the predefined InboundBasicMessaging transport chain (JFAP-TCP/IP)
specifies the predefined InboundHTTPMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTP wrappers)
specifies the predefined InboundHTTPSMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTPS wrappers)
specifies the predefined InboundSecureMessaging transport chain (JFAP-SSL-TCP/IP)
If you have access to the WebSphere Administrative Console, you can view transport chain information through the Application Servers/serverName/Transport Chain menu.
The transport chain used for message exchange need not match the chain used for bootstrap access.
Identifies the Service Integration Bus (SIB) used to access the remote WebSphere Application Server.
Enter the name of the bus is this dialog box.
A bus supports applications using message-based and service-oriented architectures. A bus is a group of interconnected servers and clusters that have been added as members of the bus.
Applications connect to a bus at one of the messaging engines associated with its bus members.

If you have access to the WebSphere Administrative Console, you can view bus information, to include bus members and messaging engines, queues and topics, and the bus-specific default topic space through the Service integration/Buses menu.

property.name: SSLCipher
