property.description: Select the IBM cipher specification used by the assigned SSL Proxy Profile when establishing a secure connection to the WebSphere Application Server. The selected specification replaces the cipher suite that is assigned as part of the SSL Proxy Profile configuration

description.p: Forces (on) or makes optional (off, the default value) the use of IBM FIPS-compliant cipher specifications.
Setting this property to on prevents the usage of non-FIPS compliant cipher specifications, and requires the use of one of the following cipher specifications.

ul.li: SSL_RSA_FIPS_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA
SSL_RSA_FIPS_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA

object.description: WebSphere JMS is responsible for messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring/polling queues, by ensuring that sent messages are directed to the correct receive queue, or that messages are routed to another queue manager.

object.name: LoadBalancerGroup

property.name: Algorithm
property.summary: Algorithm to balance the real servers.
property.description: Select the algorithm to use to balance the real servers.

property.name: Damp
property.description: When a real server is observed to be non-functioning it is temporarily disabled. When the damp time has elapsed, it will be re-enabled. Allowable values are within the range 1 through 86400 (seconds).

property.name: NeverReturnSickMember
property.summary: Block Connection Attempt When All Members Are Down
property.description: During normal operation, when all members of the load-balancing group are down and a new request for that group is made, the first member of the group is automatically selected. If this property is turned on, no attempt will be made to connect under these circumstances.

property.name: TryEveryServerBeforeFailing
property.summary: Try Every Server In Group Before Failing
property.description: If this value is set, every server in the group will be tried before failing the connection attempt. This includes servers currently dampened, as well as healthy members; it is a "last best-effort" attempt.

property.name: LBGroupChecks
property.description: The members of a Load Balancer Group can be periodically polled to verify the health of the server. If the server is found to be unresponsive, it is removed from the list of actively available servers until it passes a health check.

property.name: MasqueradeMember
property.description: If this value is set, the host name presented to the server will be the name of the group instead of the name of the member being used for that specific transaction.

object.summary: Configure the members of a virtual group

description.p: The DataPower device can distribute traffic to members of a Load Balancer Group. These are back end servers and not additional DataPower devices. A Load Balancer Group lists members of a virtual server group, and the sets the algorithm for balancing them. Periodic health checks can be performed. Load Balancers may also be used to provide redundant LDAP server access.

Once created, a Load Balancer Group can be used by one or more top level services (such as Multi-Protocol Gateway or XML Firewall) by associating the Load Balancer Group with an XML Manager in turn associated with the service. The back end destination URL is then set to the name of the Load Balancer Group (such as "BackEndServers").

object.name: LogLabel

property.name: Type
property.description: Type of Log Category

object.description: Allows for the configuration of custom log categories

property.name: MatchRules
property.description: Add, edit, or delete a matching rule

property.name: MatchWithPCRE
property.summary: Toggles matching with shell style expressions or PCREs
property.description:
Controls whether matching evaluation is done with shell based wildcards or PCRE style expressions. This does not apply to XPath evaluation.
For a PCRE expression - use .* rather than * to match any number of any characters, for example.
For a shell style wildcard match, the following wildcard characters are available when constructing a match pattern.
asterisk (*) Matches 0 or more occurrences of any character
question mark (?) Matches one occurrence of any single character
brackets ( [ ] ) Defines a character or numeric range. For example, [1-5] matches 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5, while xs[dl] matches xsd or xsl.

property.name: CombineWithOr
property.summary: Combine multiple match criteria with or style boolean operations
property.description: If multiple match criteria are present and this property is turned on, those criteria will be combined with or semantics (that is only one of those criteria needs to evaluate successfully.). If this property is turned off the matches are combined with and semantics (that is, they must all evaluate successfully for the overall match to be true.)

object.name: FilterAction

property.name: Type
property.description: Select the action to take The default is Notify.

property.name: LogLevel
property.description: Specify the priority of the log message that is generated when a monitored message type exceeds a threshold value.

property.name: BlockInterval
property.summary: The amount of time a monitor stays triggered
property.description: Specify an optional blackout period during which an over-threshold message type is denied service. Meaningful only when the message is rejected due to policy or shaping queue overflow. This value is the duration of service denial in milliseconds. The default value (0) indicates that while over-threshold messages are dropped, no service denial penalty is imposed.

object.description: On-Line Help for Monitor Policies (Filter Actions)

property.name: IPAddress
property.description: Use an IP network address and prefix length to define a contiguous range of IP addresses included in this traffic definition (for example, 10.10.100.0/28 specifies IP addresses 10.10.100.0 through 10.10.100.15, and 10.10.100.19/32 specifies a single host address).

property.name: IPExclude
property.description: Use an IP network address and prefix length to define a contiguous range of IP addresses excluded from this traffic definition (for example, 10.10.100.0/28 specifies IP addresses 10.10.100.0 through 10.10.100.15, and 10.10.100.19/32 specifies a single host address).

property.name: HTTPMethod
property.description: Select the HTTP method included in this traffic definition. The default value is any, which indicates that HTTP method is not a match criteria.

property.name: HTTPHeader
property.description: Click this tab to add match criteria for inclusive HTTP header fields to the traffic definition. The field with its corresponding value must appear in the HTTP header of the message to qualify for inclusion.

property.name: HTTPHeaderExclude
property.description: Click this tab to add match criteria for exclusive HTTP header field to the traffic definition. The field with its corresponding value cannot appear in the HTTP header of the message to qualify for exclusion.

property.name: RequestURL
property.description:
Provide a literal or wildcard expression to define a URL set included in this traffic definition. The following wildcard characters are available when defining the URL set.
asterisk (*) Matches 0 or more occurrences of any character
question mark (?) Matches one occurrence of any single character
brackets ( [ ] ) Defines a character or numeric range. For example, [1-5] matches 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5, while xs[dl] matches xsd or xsl.

description.p: Message Matching determines what messages will be monitored by any monitor that uses the Message Matching object. It is a definition of the traffic flow that is monitored.
To capture all messages, set the HTTP Method field to 'any' and leave all other fields blank.

property.name: UserSummary
property.description: A Message Monitor observes traffic that is incuded by the Message Type definition (which in turn is a collection of Message Matching objects). The Monitor measures only that traffic selected by the Measure field. On the Filters page, traffic which meets the filter criteria causes the Monitor to take the corresponding action (which is defined by a Message Filter Type object).

property.name: MessageType
property.description: Select the message type monitored by this message-count monitor.

object.name: CountMonitor

property.name: Measure
property.description: Select the action that advances the counter. The default is Requests.

property.name: Source
property.description: Select how monitoring is applied to IP addresses. This setting is meaningful only if an associated traffic definition contains and inclusive or exclusive IP address criterion. The default is All.

property.name: Header
property.summary: The name of the header to extract IP address
property.description: The name of the HTTP header to read to determine the value of the source IP address.

property.name: Filter
property.description: Click this tab to define a message-count monitor threshold and assign an action (Message Filter Action) that is taken when the threshold is reached.

property.name: MaxSources
property.description: When utilizing the each-ip aggregate addressing policy the system organizes the counts per address by the addresses most recently used. When too many distinct counts have been observed, the Addresses not seen in the longest time are discarded. This parameter specifies how many distinct addresses are tracked.

object.description: On-Line Help for Message-Count Monitors

object.name: DurationMonitor

property.name: Measure
property.description: Select which portion of the transaction cycle to monitor. The default is Messages.

property.name: Filter
property.description: Click this tab to define a message-duration monitor threshold and assign an action taken when the threshold is reached.

object.description: On-Line Help for Message-Duration Monitors. Duration Monitors observe the duration, or amount of time, taken to process submissions.

object.name: MessageType

property.name: Matching
property.summary: A list of traffic definitions assigned to this message type
property.description: Use the values list (a list of traffic definitions), in conjunction with the Add and Delete buttons, to add one or more traffic definitions to this message type. Click the + button to create a new traffic definition (Message Matching object). Select an object and click ... to edit it.

object.description: On-Line Help for Message Types

object.name: MQGW

property.name: QueueManager
property.summary: An MQ Queue Manager object name
property.description: Select a Queue Manager from the list of available Queue Managers to use for the MQ side of this gateway. For an MQ-to-HTTP gateway, this Queue Manager holds the Get Queue that is polled for requests and the Put Queue that is used for responses. For an HTTP-to-MQ gateway, this is the Queue Manager that holds the Put Queue used for requests and the Get Queue that is polled for responses.

property.name: Direction
property.summary: Defines the type of the gateway.
property.description: Select the type of gateway.

property.name: URL
property.summary: URL to use in the HTTP POST request to the proxy
property.description: This field is only relevant for an MQ-to-HTTP proxy. An MQ to HTTP proxy sends requests to the loopback address of the local DataPower system. There must be either an XSL Proxy or an XML Firewall listening at the client port number on this local machine to receive the message and respond to it. Otherwise there will be no response. The XSL Proxy or XML Firewall listening on the client port number may be configured as any type, including a loopback proxy. If it is a loopback proxy, no other hosts are required to complete the end to end transaction.

property.name: Client
property.summary: The Client interacts with the back end server.
property.description: The Client interacts with the back end server. For an MQ-to-HTTP gateway, the client polls the MQ host and acts as a client to the HTTP server.

property.name: Server
property.summary: The entity acting as the transport server
property.description: The server transport type should be MQ if the gateway is polling a queue for requests, and the type should be HTTP if the gateway is listening on a port for requests.

object.description:
A WebSphere MQ gateway takes an input request message, posts it to an internal URL (addressing an XSL Proxy or XML Firewall), waits for the response from the Firewall or proxy, and finally outputs a reply message. WebSphere gateways can be of two types.
MQ-to-HTTP Gateway - translating MQ messages to HTTP messages.
HTTP-to-MQ Gateway - translating HTTP messages to MQ messages.
An MQ-to-HTTP gateway monitors a Get queue associated with a Queue Manager residing on a remote MQ server for request messages. When messages are available for retrieval, the gateway gets the messages from the identified Queue Manager and forwards the MQ request to a backend XSL Proxy (or XML Firewall) that may perform user-specified request-side transformations, filtering, and/or security services before forwarding the (possibly transformed) request to an HTTP web or application server.
The XSL Proxy or XML Firewall may be of any type (dynamic back-end, loopback proxy or static-backend). In a similar fashion, the server response is returned through the XSL Proxy or XML Firewall (where response-side transformation, filtering, and/or security services may be performed), and forwarded to the MQ-to-HTTP gateway, which then pushes the result, as an MQ response message, back to a Put queue on the identified Queue Manager.

object.name: MQhost

property.name: QueueManager
property.description: The remote MQ Queue Manager with which this host interacts. Both the get and put queues reside on this manager. Select an existing QM from the list or click the + button to create a new MQ Queue Manager. A selection is required.

property.name: GetQueue
property.description: The exact name of a the Get queue managed by the identified Queue Manager. This host polls this queue for requests.

property.name: PutQueue
property.description: The exact name of a the Put queue managed by the identified Queue Manager. This host puts responses on this queue.

property.name: XMLManager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets and documents. The XML Manager can also control the size and depth of messages processed by this host. Select an existing XML Manager from the list or click the + button to create a new XML Manager to assign to this host. More than one service may use the same XML Manager.

property.name: ContentType
property.summary: Specify the type of content generated by a processing action
property.description: This feature is most useful if the Document Processing Rule invokes the processing actions "fetch" or "results" (where a response is expected from the remote device), This option allows the user to specify the type of content of the returned data. If the Document Processing Rule does not invoke a fetch or results action, Content Type should be set to default value (text/xml). If necessary, set ContentType to a recognized HTTP content type.

property.name: MessageType
property.summary: Characterize the body of the message.
property.description: Characterizes the body of the message. The default is XML.

property.name: Credentials
property.description: Specifies an optional Firewall Credentials list for the host. A Firewall Credentials list specifies which keys and certificates are available to support firewall processing. In the absence of an identified Firewall Credentials list, all locally-stored key and certificates are available to the firewall.

property.name: StylesheetParameters
property.description: Stylesheets used in Processing Policies can take stylesheet parameters. These parameters can be passed in by other objects, such as service objects. More than one parameter may be defined.

property.name: DefaultParameterNamespace
property.description: If a stylesheet parameter is defined without a namespace (or without explicitly specifying the null namespace), then this is the namespace into which the parameter will be assigned.

property.name: StylePolicyRule
property.description: Select an XML firewall processing policy to assign to the XML firewall. A Processing Policy establishes the actions taken on messages flowing through the firewall.

property.name: FirewallExtensions
property.summary: Enables use of cryptographic firewall extensions
property.description: Configures access to cryptographic extensions in referenced stylesheet rules. If enabled cryptographic extension functions can be used in multistep transformations.

property.name: AttachmentsMode
property.summary: Attachment processing mode for SOAP messages.
property.description: Select how to treat messages with attachments. The default is Strip.

property.name: FrontAttachmentFormat
property.summary: Attachment processing format for client requests
property.description: Select how to interpret client requests with attachments.

property.name: BackAttachmentFormat
property.description: Select the attachment output format to backend servers.

property.name: PollInterval
property.description: The interval in milliseconds between polls for messages on the Get queue. Enter an integer between 5 and 1000. The default is 100.

property.name: DebugMode
property.description: Select the diagnostic mode for processing policies. When enabled, the display includes the Probe button. The transactions captured by the probe can be used to view the state of variables and contexts for a captured transaction.

property.name: DebuggerType
property.description: Select the problem mode.

property.name: DebuggerURL
property.description: Configures the URL for external probe mode

property.name: DebugHistory
property.description:
Sets the number of transactions captured in diagnostics mode.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

property.name: DebugTrigger
property.description: The probe captures transactions that meet one or more of the conditions defined by the triggers. These triggers examine the direction or type of the message flow and examine the message for an XPath expression match. When a message meets one of these conditions, the transaction is captured in diagnostics mode and becomes part of the list of transactions that can be viewed.

property.name: CodePage
property.description: For MQCCSI_EMBEDDED enter 4294967295; for MQCCSI_INHERIT enter 4294967294

property.name: SOAPSchemaURL
property.summary: Specifies which W3C XML Schema will be used to validate SOAP documents
property.description: When a firewall is in SOAP mode, either on the request or response side, it will validate the incoming messages against a W3C Schema that defines what a SOAP message is supposed to look like. It is possible to customize which schema is used on a per-firewall basis by changing this property; this can be used to accomodate non-standard configurations or other special cases.

property.name: CountMonitors
property.description: Count Monitors watch for defined messaging events and increment counters each time the event occurs. When a certain threshold is reached, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Count Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Count Monitor.

property.name: DurationMonitors
property.description: Duration Monitors watch for events meeting or exceeding a configured duration. When a duration is met or exceeded, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Duration Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Duration Monitor.

property-group.name: ProbeSettings
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional Probe settings
property-group.description:
The MultiStep Probe allows developers to view the changing value of variables and the changing contents of processing contexts. The developer can step through each action for any given transaction, up to a configured number of transactions. The Probe Settings page turns on this debugging tool and also sets the number of concurrently captured transactions.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

object.description: A WebSphere MQ Host polls a get queue on a designated queue manager that other MQ hosts on a TCP/IP network can send requests to, and, after applying a Document Processing Rule, outputs a response to a put queue on the same queue manager. This is similar to a loopback proxy or firewall that provides transformation and/or security services.

object.name: MQproxy

property.name: FrontQueueManager
property.description: The Front Queue Manager holds the Request Get and Response Put Queues. Select the Queue Manager from the list of available Queue Managers or click the + button to create a new Queue Manager.

property.name: BackQueueManager
property.description: The Back Queue Manager holds the Response Get and Request Put Queues. Select the Queue Manager from the list of available Queue Managers or click the + button to create a new Queue Manager.

property.name: Concurrent
property.summary: The maximum number of outstanding concurrent messages.
property.description: The maximum number of in-flight messages for this proxy. Note that messages awaiting a response from the Back Queue Manager are counted in the concurrent number. Enter an integer between 1 and 5000.

property.name: WaitTimeout
property.description: The maximum time in milliseconds to wait for a response. Enter an integer between 5 and 3600000. The default is 6000.

property.name: FirewallExtensions
property.description: Configures access to cryptographic extensions in referenced stylesheet rules. If enabled cryptographic extension functions can be used in multistep transformations.

property.name: RequestGetQueue
property.description: The queue polled for request messages, residing on the Front Queue Manager. The string entered here must match exactly to the queue name.

property.name: RequestPutQueue
property.description: The queue used to place requests on the Back Queue Manager. The string entered here must match exactly to the queue name.

property.name: ResponseGetQueue
property.description: The queue polled for response messages, residing on the Back Queue Manager. The string entered here must match exactly to the queue name. Note that the MQ Proxy will remain connected to this Queue for 60 seconds after receiving a response, to reduce the number of handshakes with the queue.

property.name: ResponsePutQueue
property.description: The queue used to put response messages, residing on the Front Queue Manager. The string entered here must match exactly to the queue name.

property.name: XMLManager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets, the caching of documents, and provides configuration constraints on the size and parsing depth of documents. You can enable streaming operation by configuring an XML Manager to use a Streaming Compile Option Policy. More than one firewall may use the same XML Manager. Select an existing XML Manager from the list to assign the Manager to this MQ Proxy. Click the + button to create a new XML Manager that is assigned to this MQ Proxy. A default Manager is used if you do not create one.

property.name: ContentType
property.summary: A content type for documents retrieved during processing.
property.description: Specify the type of content generated by a specific action. This feature is most useful if the Processing Rule invokes an action type of fetch or results (if a response is expected from the remote device). This allows the administrator to specify the type of content of fetched and/or returned data. The type may determine other processing steps (such as schema validation for SOAP content). If the Processing Rule does not invoke a fetch or results action, Content Type should be set to default value (text/xml). If necessary, set ContentType to a recognized HTTP content type.

property.name: RequestType
property.description: Characterizes the traffic that originates from the client. The default is SOAP.

property.name: ResponseType
property.description: Characterizes the traffic that originates from the server. The default is SOAP.

property.name: Credentials
property.description: Specifies an optional Firewall Credentials list for the XML firewall. A Firewall Credentials list specifies which keys and certificates are available to support firewall processing. In the absence of an identified Firewall Credentials list, all locally-stored key and certificates are available to the firewall.

property.name: StylesheetParameters
property.summary: Parameters passed to stylesheets during processing.
property.description: Stylesheets used in Processing Policies can take stylesheet parameters. These parameters can be passed in by this object. More than one parameter can be defined.

property.name: DefaultParameterNamespace
property.description: If a stylesheet parameter is defined without a namespace (or without explicitly specifying the null namespace), then this is the namespace into which the parameter will be assigned.

property.name: RequestStylePolicyRule
property.summary: Assign a processing rule for requests
property.description: Select an existing processing policy to assign to the proxy. The selected policy will be run against all messages retrieved from the Request Get Queue. The result will be placed on the Request Put Queue. A Processing Policy establishes the actions taken on messages flowing through this proxy.

property.name: ResponseStylePolicyRule
property.summary: Assign a processing rule for responses
property.description: Select an existing processing policy to assign to the proxy. The selected policy will be run against all messages retrieved from the Response Get Queue. The result will be placed on the Response Put Queue. A Processing Policy establishes the actions taken on messages flowing through this proxy.

property.name: ErrorStylePolicyRule
property.summary: Assign a processing rule for errors
property.description: Select an existing processing policy to assign to the proxy. The selected policy will be run when errors are encountered. A Processing Policy establishes the actions taken on messages flowing through this proxy.

property.name: RequestAttachments
property.summary: Attachment processing mode for client requests
property.description: Select how to treat client requests with attachments. The default is Strip.

property.name: ResponseAttachments
property.summary: Attachment processing mode for server responses
property.description: Select how to treat server responses with attachments. The default is Strip.

property.name: RootPartNotFirstAction
property.display: Action when root part is not first
property.description: When streaming MIME messages, the action to take when the root part is not the first part of the message. If the root part must be first (for example to do BSP conformance checking) and the action is set to process in order the DP device will buffer attachments up to the root.

property.name: FrontAttachmentFormat
property.summary: Attachment processing format for client requests
property.description: Select how to interpret client requests with attachments.

property.name: BackAttachmentFormat
property.description: Select the attachment output format to backend servers.

property.name: PollInterval
property.description: The amount of time in milliseconds between polls. Enter an integer between 5 and 1000. The default is 100.

property.name: DebugMode
property.description: Select the diagnostic mode for processing policies. When enabled, the display includes the Probe button. The transactions captured by the probe can be used to view the state of variables and contexts for a captured transaction.

property.name: DebuggerType
property.description: Select the probe mode.

property.name: DebuggerURL
property.description: Configures the URL for external probe mode

property.name: DebugHistory
property.description:
Sets the number of transactions captured in diagnostics mode.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

property.name: DebugTrigger
property.description: The probe captures transactions that meet one or more of the conditions defined by the triggers. These triggers examine the direction or type of the message flow and examine the message for an XPath expression match. When a message meets one of these conditions, the transaction is captured in diagnostics mode and becomes part of the list of transactions that can be viewed.

property.name: SOAPSchemaURL
property.summary: Specifies which W3C XML Schema will be used to validate SOAP documents
property.description: When a firewall is in SOAP mode, either on the request or response side, it will validate the incoming messages against a W3C Schema that defines what a SOAP message is supposed to look like. It is possible to customize which schema is used on a per-firewall basis by changing this property; this can be used to accomodate non-standard configurations or other special cases.

property.name: CountMonitors
property.description: Count Monitors watch for defined messaging events and increment counters each time the event occurs. When a certain threshold is reached, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Count Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Count Monitor.

property.name: DurationMonitors
property.description: Duration Monitors watch for events meeting or exceeding a configured duration. When a duration is met or exceeded, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Duration Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Duration Monitor.

property-group.name: ProbeSettings
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional Probe settings

object.description: A WebSphere MQ Proxy processes MQ-to-MQ transactions. A WebSphere MQ proxy mediates between two MQ queue pairs and runs a single unidirectional Document Processing Rule for XML data that flows between the MQ queue pairs. The Proxy polls the RequestGetQueue of the Front Queue Manager for messages, operates on the message in accordance with the Processing Rules established for the proxy (if any apply), and places the result on the RequestPutQueue of the Back Queue Manager. The proxy then polls the ResponseGetQueue of the Back Queue Manager for responses and operates on the message in accordance with the Processing Rules established for the proxy (if any apply), and places the result on the ResponsePutQueue of the Front Queue Manager. The Processing Rule can perform any number of XSLT transformations and/or security services on the transient data.

object.name: MQQM

property.name: HostName
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the WebSphere MQ server where the queue manager is running. Specify the value as "hostname:portnumber" (for example, "10.10.1.2:1414") or "hostname(portnumber)" (for example, "10.10.1.2(1414)"). If the port number is not specified, the default is 1414.

property.name: QMname
property.description: Specify the name of the queue manager when the queue manager is not the default on the identified host.

property.name: CCSID
property.description: Specify the CCSID to present to the Queue Manager when the DataPower appliance connects to it. This setting has the same effect as setting the MQCCSID environment variable for an MQ client. Refer to the WebSphere MQ Information Center for more information and a list of specific CCSID values. Unless necessary, use the default value.

property.name: ChannelName
property.description: Specify the name of the channel to use as an alternative to the default SYSTEM.DEF.SVRCONN.

property.name: Heartbeat
property.description: Specify the approximate time in seconds between heartbeat flows on a channel when waiting for a message on a queue. Use an integer between 0 and 999999. If 0, there will not be heartbeat flows exchanged when waiting for a message on the channel. This property does not set the heartbeat on the channel. Instead, it is used to negotiate the heartbeat value with the channel. The greater of the two values is used.

property.name: UserName
property.description: Specify the plaintext string to sentd to the server for identifying the client.

property.name: MaximumMessageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of messages to accept
property.description: Specify the maximum size in bytes of allowed messages. Messages that are bigger than this size are rejected. Use an integer between 1024 and 1073741824.

property.name: CacheTimeout
property.summary: Maximum period to retain a dynamic connection in the connection cache

description.p: Specify the number of seconds that the DataPower appliance retains (keeps alive) a dynamic connection in the connection cache. Use a value that is greater than the negotiated heartbeat interval but less than the keep alive interval.

ul.li: The negotiated heartbeat interval is between the DataPower appliance and the backend MQ server. Use the Channel Heartbeat property to define the starting value for the negotiation.

The keep alive (timeout) interval is on the backend MQ server. The KAINT attribute on the MQ server defines the timeout value for a channel. Not all channels have a defined, explicit keep alive interval on the MQ server. Some queue managers use an automatic timeout setting (the KAINT attribute set to AUTO). In these cases, the keep alive interval is the negotiated heartbeat interval plus 60 seconds.

description.p: When an inactive connection reaches this threshold, the DataPower appliance removes that dynamic connection from the cache. When the cache no longer contains dynamic connections, the DataPower appliance deletes the dynamic queue manager. Without a dynamic queue manager, there is no connection with the backend MQ server.

Note: The timeout value for the Cache Timeout property is the only way to configure a timeout value from the DataPower appliance to the backend MQ server. No other configuration setting on the DataPower appliance can time out an MQ connection.

When set to 0 (zero), the default, causes the appliance to get and put messages with no provision for roll back. Either the operation succeeds or not. Undeliverable messages are silently discarded, which leaves higher level protocols with the responsibility to detect and retransmit lost packets

When set to 1, the DataPower appliance uses synch points. A synch point commits and rolls back each MQ message, not the entire transaction. When specified, the DataPower appliance does not remove the message that it gets from a queue unitl it completes its transaction using that message (such as placing the message on a server queue for processing). If the transaction fails and the message is left available on the queue, the DataPower appliance can attempt to get the message and process it again.

p.b: Only the values 0 (zero) or 1 are valid.

property.name: AutomaticBackout
property.summary: Enables automatic routing of undeliverable messages

description.p: Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the automatic backout of poison messages. A poison message is any message that the receiving application does not know how to process.
Usually an application rolls back the GET of this message, which leaves the message on the input queue. However, the backout count (MQMD.Backoutcount) is incremented.

As the MQ Queue Manager object continues to re-get the message, the backout count continues to increase. When the backout count exceeds the backout threshold, the MQ Queue Manager object moves the message to the backout queue.

If disabled, the poison message remains on the GET queue and continue to be reprocessed by the appliance until the Queue Manager that manages the GET queue removes it or the appliance reroutes the offending message. The message could be rerouted by a custom style sheet in the request rule.

property.name: BackoutThreshold
property.description: Specify the maximum number of reprocessing attempts to allow per message. During processing, the count starts at 0, which accounts for the initial reception of a message. If the initial attempt fails, the backout count is set to 1. After one failed attempt to reprocess the message, the count is set to 2. Therefore, the default value of 1 specifies two attempts: the initial attempt and a single reprocessing attempt.

property.name: BackoutQueueName
property.description: Specify the queue to contains messages that exceeded the backout threshold. This queue must be managed by the same MQ Queue Manager as the defined GET queue. The backout queue, typically SYSTEM.DEAD.LETTER.QUEUE contains messages that cannot be processed or delivered.

property.name: TotalConnectionLimit
property.description: Specify the total number of open connections to allow. Use an integer between 2 and 5000.

property.name: InitialConnections
property.description: Specify the number of connections to open immediately when the MQ Queue Manager object starts. Use an integer between 0 and 5000.

description.p: Specify the location of the key database file in which keys and certificates are stored.
Use this property with the SSL Cipher property to enable SSL communication when the SSL artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit).
Note: To integrate with MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the SSL Proxy Profile property.

Each key database file has an associated stash file. The stash file holds encrypted passwords that allow programmatic access to the key database. The stash file must reside in the same directory as the key database file, have the same file naem as the key database file, and have the .sth file extension. For example, if the key database file is MQkeys.pem or MQkeys.kidb , the stash file must be MQkeys.sth .
If these file are not on the appliance, upload or fetch them.
Select the cipher suite for SSL communication when using an SSL key repository. The cipher suite must match the ciphers in use by the MQ Queue Manager.
Use this property with the SSL Key Repository property to enable SSL communication when the SSL artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit).
Note: To integrate with MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the SSL Proxy Profile property.
Select an SSL Proxy Profile.

The following table maps the relationship between the SSL Cipher Specification property and the setting required on the Crypto Profile of the SSL Proxy Profile that is assigned to the MQ Queue Manager. Use this information when configuring the SSL Proxy Profile to communicate with the MQ Queue Manager.

property.name: ConvertInput
property.summary: Enable conversion of the incoming message to the default CCSI

description.p: Indicates whether the queue manager can convert input messages to a different CCSI (Coded Character Set Identifier) than the one in the incoming message. This conversion is done by the remote queue manager, not the DataPower device.
Click off to disable automatic conversion of incoming messages to the CCSI established for this MQ Queue Manager object. Use the Character Code Set ID property on the Advanced tab.

Define whether to attempt to reconnect to remote server after a connection failure. When set to on , the DataPower appliance automatically attempt to reconnect to the remote host. This is on by default.
Note: This setting does not affect attempts to put or get messages over an established connection.

Specify the number of seconds to wait before attempting to retry failed connections to a remote host. Note: This setting does not affect attempts to put or get messages over an established connection.

property.name: ReportingInterval
property.summary: Log a failure as an error at this interval
property.description: Specify the number of seconds between the creation of log messages at the error level when failed connections are retried. This setting filters the generation of identical error messages to MQ logging targets. When set to 0 (zero), only only debug level messages are sent.

description.p: Determines whether to use the MQOD.AlternateUserId as the value of the User Name property.
When enabled (on), uses MQOD.AlternateUserId . When disabled, uses MQMD.UserIdentifier .

Specify the local address for outbound connections to a specific local interface and port. Supported formats are 1.1.1.1 or 1.1.1.1(1) or just (1) to tell TCP to bind to port 1 and for a range of ports use (1,10) or 1.1.1.1(1,10).
Note: If the port is set, the range must be greater than the total number of allowed connections.

property.name: XMLManager
property.description: Select an XML Manager.

object.description: In WebSphere MQ, distributed send and receive queues are managed by a component called a queue manager. The queue manager provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring/polling queues, by ensuring that sent messages are directed to the correct receive queue, or that messages are routed to another queue manager. This Queue Manager object on the device corresponds to a Queue Manager running on another host on the network. The properties set here enable communication between the device and the Queue Manager.

object.name: MQQMGroup

property.name: PrimaryQueueManager
property.description: Select an existing MQ Queue Manager object to serve as the primary Queue Manager for this group. All connections for this group will go to the Queue Manager designated. If this Queue Manager becomes unavailable, the Queue Managers listed in the Backup MQ Queue Managers will be used instead.

property.name: BackupQueueManagers
property.description: Select an existing MQ Queue Manager object and then click Add to establish a backup Queue Manager. Repeat this sequence as many times as needed to add the desired Queue Managers to the backup list. The device uses backup Queue Managers in the order in which they are listed, top to bottom. Use the Arrow icons to reorder the list. Use the X icon to delete a Manager from the list.

object.description: An MQ Queue Manager Group enables automatic failover between Queue Managers when one (or more) Queue Manager becomes unavailable.

object.name: MTOMPolicy

property.name: Mode
property.description:
Specify the optimization mode.
The encode option optimizes (serializes) input messages. For serialization, provide an XPath expression or a list of XPath expressions to identify the content to extract. Optionally, per XPath expression, exercise control over the Content Type and Content ID values. These two values can be determined automatically using the xmlmime:contentType declaration and namespace declaration.
The decode option decodes (deserializes) attachment parts of an optimized message. Deserialization, by default, reassembles the original infoset, which results in either a SOAP document or MIME document depending on whether all attachments were referenced by <Include/> elements. Optionally, you can specify a Content ID to select individual attachment parts to reassemble.

description.p: Select whether to include the xmlmine:contentType declaration in output messages when the input message does not contain this declaration. If the input message contains this declaration, the MTOM policy passes through the attribute regardless of the setting for this property.

ul.li: Select "on", the default value, to add the contentType declaration to the output message.
Select "off" to not add the contentType declaration to the output message.

property.name: Rule
property.description: Each MTOM rule describes which message elements to optimize. A single XPath expression selects one or more elements for optimization.

object.description: An MTOM policy provides a mechanism for optimizing the transmission and wire format of an XML/SOAP message. Optimization is performed by selecting elements with base64-encoded character data. The selected elements are decoded and attached as MIME attachment parts before transmission. Decoding before transmission reduces the overhead that is associated with base64-encoded data.

object.name: NameValueProfile

property.name: MaxAttributes
property.description: The maximum number of name value pairs allowed in a single entity (header, cookie set, body, and so forth).

property.name: MaxAggregateSize
property.summary: Maximum total size of name value submission
property.description: The lengths of all the names and values in a single entity (header, cookie set, body, query string, and so forth) in aggregate must not exceed this property.

property.name: MaxNameSize
property.summary: Maximum length of an individual name
property.description: The maximum size of a name attribute used in this profile.

property.name: MaxValueSize
property.summary: Maximum length of an individual value
property.description: The maximum size of a value attribute used in this profile.

property.name: ValidationList
property.description: Each pair submitted to this profile consults this validation list, looking for the first regular expression match of the name against the name expression in the list. When that is found, the corresponding value constraint is matched against the value portion of the name-value pair. If that does not match, the policy applies the 'fixup' attribute to the submitted value. That may result in no change, the pair being removed, an error being generated, or the value being mapped to a known constant.

property.name: DefaultFixup
property.summary: Policy for names that are in validation list
property.description: Select the action to taken when no matching entry in the validation list is found. The default is Strip.

property.name: DefaultMapValue
property.summary: Map unmatched value to this constant
property.description: An value that does not have a matching entry in the validation list is changed to this value if the no match policy is 'set'.

property.name: DefaultXSS
property.summary: Check the value for Cross Site Scripting signatures on values without a validation entry
property.description: This property allows the value to checked for Cross Site Scripting (sometimes called CSS or XSS) signatures. These signatures are generally attempts to obfuscate the real meaning of the value if the value were displayed directly in a browser. You want to validate any data that might get stored and displayed again later - such as the contents of a comment form. The check looks for escaped characters, characters with the high-bit set, and various forms of the term <script which is often used to engage java script on a browser without the user knowing.

object.description: Many HTTP things are expressed as name value pairs. These include HTTP headers, cookie values, url-encoded query strings, and url-encoded request messages. This profile provides a mechanism for what kinds of names are expected and for each kind of name what properties should be enforced on the corresponding values. When a name-value pair is not validated successfully that may generate an error, the pair might be stripped from the transaction, or the value may be mapped to another default value.

object.name: DNSNameService

property.name: SearchDomains
property.description: A list of domain names that will be searched if a partial host name is submitted to the DNS service. Use the text box and the Add and Delete buttons to maintain the list.

property.name: NameServers
property.description: Specify one or more DNS servers

property.name: StaticHosts
property.summary: Static host name to IP address mapping
property.description: Under user control manually maps a host name to the host IP addresse without using DNS. Note that the device's DNS name resolver uses a cache, so static mappings will not usually result in significant performance improvements.

object.description: Configure the DNS name resolution service

object.name: HostAlias

property.name: IPAddress
property.summary: The IP address corresponding to the alias.

object.summary: Static host alias to IP address mapping
object.description: Maps a host IP address to a host alias. The host alias is resolved like a static host entry. This provides a level of abstraction between concrete network addresses and configuration. These aliases may be used in place of IP addresses when configuring other objects, such as proxies and firewalls. Use host aliases to ease the export and migration of service configurations between DataPower systems. The alias is exported but the alias mapping is not; if the alias is defined on the destination system, it resolves to the IP address defined on the destination system.

object.name: NetworkSettings

property.name: ICMPDisable
property.description: Select ICMP replies to be disabled.

property.name: ECNDisable
property.description: Set toggle on to disable generation of ECN capable TCP sessions. By default, TCP sessions are ECN enabled.

property.name: DestinationRouting
property.summary: Perform outgoing interface selection based on source or destination address

description.p: Control the way that the DataPower system determines the route to return the response (the outbound packet) to the originating client (destination of the outbound packet).

When disabled (off) the default, interface selection is based on the interface that is bound to the address of the service that generated the response. If the service is bound to a single address, responses are routed using the interface that is assigned to that address. If the service is bound to more than one address (a configuration of 0.0.0.0), responses are routed using the interface that received the original client request (not the interface that is bound to the service that generated the response).

When enabled (on), interface selection is based on the best path to the client, irrespective of the service or receiving interface. Best path is determined by static routes bound to the available interfaces. Destination-based routing is for backward compatibility only. Enable destination-based routing only if an upgrade disables existing connectivity.

property.name: AllowCrosstalkOnSubnet
property.summary: Allow packets received on wrong interface if both interfaces are on same subnet.
property.description: As a security policy, the interface receiving a network packet must also be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling this option relaxes that restriction so that the packet is allowed if the interface it arrives on contains an IP address in the same subnet as the destination address of the packet. This option should be set to on if Destination Based Routing is also on.

property.name: AllowAllCrosstalk
property.summary: Allow packets received on one interface destined for a service on another.
property.description: As a security policy, the interface receiving a network packet must also be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling this option relaxes that restriction.

property.name: TCPSYNRetries
property.summary: Number of times to resend a TCP SYN
property.description: This option sets the number of times the local system will attempt to resend a TCP SYN that receives no response. Enter an integer between 1 and 32. The default is 5.

property.name: ArpRetries
property.summary: Number of times to retry a failed ARP
property.description: This option sets the number of times the local system will retry a failed ARP request. Enter an integer between 1 and 64. The default is 8.

property.name: ArpInterval
property.summary: Milliseconds to wait before retrying failed ARP
property.description: This option sets the number of milliseconds to wait before retrying a failed ARP request. Enter an integer between 10 and 5000. The default is 50.

property.name: TCPSegmentationOffload
property.summary: Ethernet device performs TCP Segmentation Offload.
property.description: By default, all of the Ethernet device drivers and chips are allowed to perform TCP Segmentation Offload. This is an Ethernet chip feature that improves performance on large TCP writes to the network. On rare occasions this feature may interact poorly on a deployed network by causing link layer resets. This configuration option allows disabling TCP Segmenration Offload on all Ethernet interfaces. Disable this only if customer support has diagnosed that you are encountering this problem. After re-enabling TCP Segmentation Offload, it is necessary to restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

property.name: ReversePathFiltering
property.display: Ignore packets with a source address that the interface cannot route
property.description: By default, incoming packets with a source address that cannot be routed by that interface will be accepted and processed. Enabling this means that such packets will be ignored, effectively disabling "source routing."

object.description: Configure system-wide network settings

object.name: NTPService

property.name: Mode
property.description: Select on to enable NTP; select off (the default setting) to disable NTP.

property.name: RemoteServer
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of a remote NTP server

property.name: RefreshInterval
property.description: An integer (within the range 60 through 86400, with a default of 900) that specifies the number of seconds between clock synchronizations.

object.description: Configure remote NTP (Network Time Protocol) server. This allows the automatic synchronization of the system clock.

object.name: NFSClientSettings

property.name: MountRefreshTime
property.description: The status of each NFS mount is checked at this interval. This is done to quickly detect NFS servers that are down, so that there will not be application-level NFS timeouts waiting for them. This is also how often they are checked when they are down, trying to bring them back up.

property.name: KerberosKeytab
property.summary: Keytab for mounts using Kerberos 5 Authentication.
property.description: This is the Kerberos Keytab to use to find the principal to use to authenticate NFS mounts using Kerberos 5 authentication. This Kerberos Keytab must be in the default application domain. There must be a principal in this Keytab with a service of nfs, with the name being the DNS name of this machine, with the appropriate Realm. Note that the KDCs and Realms used are those specified in the default application domain.

object.description: Use this page to configure global NFS client parameters. This is the global configuration for enabling NFS.

object.name: NFSDynamicMounts

property.name: Version
property.summary: Preferred NFS protocol version for dynamic NFS mounts.
property.description: Preferred NFS protocol version for dynamic NFS mounts. If the Version is 3, but the server only implements Version 2, the client will fall back to Version 2. But if the Version is 4, there is no fallback, since the remote export paths are not the same.

property.name: Transport
property.description: Transport protocol to start with for dynamic NFS mounts. If TCP is selected and it is not available on the NFS server, UDP will be used instead. When NFS version 4 is selected, this option is ignored and always defaults to TCP.

property.name: Authentication
property.description: Authentication protocol to use for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: ReadOnly
property.summary: Allow only file reads on dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: ReadSize
property.summary: Size of read operations for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: WriteSize
property.summary: Size of write operations for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Time until first retransmission is sent on an RPC timeout, for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: Retransmissions
property.summary: Number of minor RPC timeouts and retransmissions until major timeout, for dynamic NFS mounts.

property.name: IdleUnmountSeconds
property.summary: How many seconds an dynamic NFS mount will be left mounted with no file activity until it gets unmounted. Setting it to 0 disables automatic unmounting.

property.name: MountTimeoutSeconds
property.summary: How many seconds the system will attempt to retry a dynamic NFS mount until it gives up, and causes the related file open(s) to fail.

object.description: Use this page to configure the parameters of dynamic NFS mounts for dpnfs: URL fetches. These mounts support access via URLs of the form dpnfs://hostname/path/file, causing the directory hostname:/path to be automatically mounted by NFS. It remains mounted until it times out for inactivity.

object.name: NFSStaticMount

property.name: remote
property.summary: Exported NFS file system to mount.
property.description: Specifies remote NFS-exported filesystem to mount. In the form host:/path, where host is the DNS name or IP address of the NFS server, and path is the path exported by the host to mount.

property.name: LocalFilesystemAccess
property.summary: Allow local filesystem access through folder nfs-name:.
property.description: If enabled, makes the NFS mount available for filesystem access through the command line interface, under the folder name nfs- mountName , where mountName is the name of this mount.

property.name: Version
property.summary: Preferred version of NFS protocol to use.
property.description: Preferred NFS protocol version for this mount. If the Version is 3, but the server only implements Version 2, the client will fall back to Version 2. But if the Version is 4, there is no fallback, since the remote export paths are not the same.

property.name: Transport
property.description: Select the transport protocol to start with. For NFS versions 2 and 3, if TCP is selected and it is not available on the NFS server, UDP will be used instead. When NFS version 4 is selected, this option is ignored and always defaults to TCP.

property.name: Authentication
property.description: Authentication protocol to use for this NFS mount.

property.name: ReadOnly
property.summary: Allow only file reads on this mount.

property.name: Timeout
property.summary: Time until first retransmission on RPC timeout.

property.name: Retransmissions
property.summary: Number of minor RPC timeouts and retransmissions until major timeout.

object.description: Use this page to create a static NFS mount, for URL or filesystem access. These mounts will be kept mounted whenever their application domain is up.

object.name: PeerGroup

property.name: Type
property.description: Select the type of peer group. Members of the peer group exchange information of the selected type.

description.p: Enter the URL to use for exchanging information with other peers (for example, 192.168.12.100:5550) and click Add. Any number of peers may be added. The URL for the local device must be added to this list.
Note that 5550 is the default port used by the device for exchanging this type of information; this number may be altered on each device through the XML Management Interface configuration page.

object.description: A set of device peers. These peers automatically update each other with real time data of the type selected. For example, an SLM peer group exchanges counter information, allowing for the enforcement of an SLM policy across devices.

object.name: PolicyAttachments

property.name: EnforcementMode
property.description: When filter is selected, policy creates configuration which will reject client requests and client responses that do not satisfy policy. When enforce is selected, policy creates configuration which will possibly transform client requests and client responses. For example, if a policy requires a client response to be encrypted, filter will reject and trigger multistep error handling if the output is not encrypted; enforce will encrypt the outgoing content.

property.name: PolicyReferences
property.description: Enable policies attached to WSDL using PolicyURI attributes and PolicyReference elements. These attachments are sometimes called XML element attachments. If 'off', all PolicyURI attributes and PolicyReference elements are ignored and only external policies are enforced.

property.name: IgnoredPolicyAttachmentPoints
property.description: Disable all policies attached by policy references at a configured attachment point leaving other policy references intact.

property.name: ExternalPolicy
property.description: Associate an external policy with a service.

object.summary: WS-Policy Internal and External Policy Attachment
object.description: Create and configure ws-policy attachments for WSDLs

object.name: PolicyParameters

property.name: PolicyParameter
property.description: A key-value pair. The key specifies a policy parameter in a policy mapping stylesheet formatted {policy-domain-ns}key.

object.description: Configuration to persist the values of ws-policy parameters.

object.name: RaidVolume

property.name: ReadOnly
property.summary: Access permission to files on the storage volume
property.description: Set the access permission to files on the storage volume. When set to "on", the access permission is read-only. When set to "off", the default value, the access permission is read-write.

property.name: Directory
property.description: Specify the subdirectory in the local: and logstore: directories where the files on the storage volume are available. Each application domain contains these subdirectories. These subdirectories are not shared across application domains. The name can be up to 64 characters long. The name cannot start with a period. The name can consist of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numeric digits, dashes, underscores, and periods.

object.summary: Hard disk array auxiliary data storage
object.description: The configuration of a hard disk array as auxiliary data storage. The hard disk array consists of two hard disk drives in a RAID-1 (mirrored) configuration.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

object.name: MgmtInterface

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Allows users to specify an existing SSL proxy profile and assign the SSL proxy profile to xml-mgmt instead of the default profile, or create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to xml-mgmt instead of the default profile.

property.name: UserAgent
property.description: Allows users to specify an existing User Agent and assign the User Agent to xml-mgmt, or create a new User Agent and assign that User Agent to xml-mgmt.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to xml-mgmt based on the IP address of the client.

property.name: WSManagement
property.description: This setting has been deprecated.

property.name: SLMPeering
property.summary: How often to push out SLM updates
property.description: Defines how often the scheduled task to push out SLM updates should run, in seconds.

property.name: Mode
property.description: Select which services to enable. For each service that you enable, you can use the XML Management Interface to control it.

object.description: Configure the XML management interface. This interface is described in the xml-mgmt.wsdl file found in the store: directory of the default domain.

object.name: SSHService

property.name: Mode
property.description: Select on to enable SSH; select off to disable SSH (the default condition).

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The TCP port monitored by SSH
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 22) that identifies the TCP port monitored by the SSH service.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client.

object.description: Configures the SSH server

object.name: TelnetService

property.name: LocalPort
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 2300) that specifies the TCP monitored by the telnet server

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client.

object.description: Creates a telnet service. When enabled, administrators can telnet into the device.

object.name: WebGUI

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Allows users to specify an existing SSL proxy profile and assign the SSL proxy profile to web-mgmt instead of the default profile, or create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to web-mgmt instead of the default profile.

property.name: UserAgent
property.description: Allows users to specify an existing User Agent and assign the User Agent to web-mgmt, or create a new User Agent and assign that User Agent to web-mgmt.

property.name: SaveConfigOverwrites
property.description: When enabled, the Save Config button will overwrite the saved startup config with a copy of the running config. When disabled, a manual step is required, to prevent overwriting a hand-edited startup config.

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.description: The time after which an idle session will be invalidated, requiring reauthentication. To disable the idle timer altogether, use the value '0'.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to web-mgmt based on the IP address of the client.

object.description: Configure the web GUI Management interface.

object.name: HTTPProxyService

property.name: Priority
property.description: Control the service scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority services will be favored over lower priority services.

property.name: LocalPort
property.description: Specify the local port to monitor for incoming client requests.

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.summary: Host name, IP address, or Load Balancer Group
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the specific server supported by this XSL Proxy or XML Firewall. If using load balancers, specify the name of the Load Balancer Group. Used only when Type is static-backend.

property.name: RemotePort
property.description: Specify the port number to monitor. Used only when Type is static-backend.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

property.name: HTTPTimeout
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 3 through 86400, with a default of 120) that a firewall or proxy maintains an idle HTTP connection.

property.name: HTTPPersistTimeout
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 0 through 7200, with a default of 180) that a firewall or proxy maintains an idle TCP connection.

property.name: DoHostRewrite
property.description: When enabled, the device will rewrite the Host: header to be the address of the back-end server. This is not what a strict proxy would do, and may not be appropriate for all topologies.

property.name: SuppressHTTPWarnings
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the generation of Transformation Applied (Warning Code: 214) messages by the HTTP service.

property.name: HTTPCompression
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression function.

property.name: HTTPIncludeResponseTypeEncoding
property.summary: Include the character set encoding in the HTTP content-type header
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable including the character set encoding in the HTTP content-type header produced. For example, when sending a UTF-8 encoded XML document: If this property is disabled, 'content-type=text/xml' will be sent. If this property is enabled, 'content-type=text/xml; charset=UTF-8' will be sent.

property.name: AlwaysShowErrors
property.summary: Provide full error reports even when inline with other documents.
property.description: If set, HTTP responses may be generated with errors appended to partially generated documents. If not set error responses will only be sent to the browser if no other output has been created.

property.name: DisallowGet
property.summary: Do not allow clients to do GET and HEAD
property.description: If set, only methods with incoming data (such as POST) are allowed.

property.name: DisallowEmptyResponse
property.summary: Require all responses to have bodies
property.description: If set, only responses with message bodies are allowed (that is, not 304 and so forth).

property.name: HTTPPersistentConnections
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable HTTP persistent connections.

property.name: HTTPClientIPLabel
property.summary: HTTP header label containing client IP address
property.description: Retain the default value (X-Client-IP) or provide an other value (for example, X-Forwarded-For).

property.name: HTTPProxyHost
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the HTTP proxy to use when the remote server can be accessed only through another HTTP proxy.

property.name: HTTPProxyPort
property.description: Specify the port number on the HTTP proxy server.

property.name: DoChunkedUpload
property.description: Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the ability to send Content-Type Chunked Encoded documents to the back end server. When the device employs the HTTP/1.1 protocol, the body of the document can be delimited by either Content-Length or chunked encodings. While all servers will understand how to interpret Content-Length, many applications will fail to understand Chunked encoding. For this reason, Content-Length is the standard method used. However doing so interferes with the ability of the device to fully stream. To stream full documents towards the back end server, this property should be turned on. However, the back end server must be RFC 2616 compatible, because this feature cannot be renegotiated at run time, unlike all other HTTP/1.1 features which can be negotiated down at runtime if necessary. This property can also be enabled by configuring a User Agent to enable it on a per-URL basis.

property.name: HeaderSuppression
property.description: HTTP Headers can be suppressed (removed) from the message flow using this property. For example, the Via: header, which contains the name of the DataPower service handling the message, may be suppressed from messages sent by the DataPower device back to the client.

property.name: StylesheetParameters
property.description: Stylesheets used in Processing Policies can take stylesheet parameters. These parameters can be passed in by this object. More than one parameter can be defined.

property.name: DefaultParamNamespace
property.description: If a stylesheet parameter is defined without a namespace (or without explicitly specifying the null namespace), then this is the namespace into which the parameter will be assigned.

property.name: QueryParamNamespace
property.description: The namespace in which to put all parameters that are specified in the URL query string.

property.name: CountMonitors
property.description: Count Monitors watch for defined messaging events and increment counters each time the event occurs. When a certain threshold is reached, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Count Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Count Monitor.

property.name: DurationMonitors
property.description: Duration Monitors watch for events meeting or exceeding a configured duration. When a duration is met or exceeded, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Duration Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Duration Monitor.

property.name: MonitorProcessingPolicy
property.description: Select the way that the system behaves when more than one monitor is attached to a service.

property.name: DebugMode
property.description: Select the diagnostic mode for processing policies. When enabled, the display includes the Probe button. The transactions captured by the probe can be used to view the state of variables and contexts for a captured transaction.

property.name: DebuggerType
property.description: Select the probe mode.

property.name: DebuggerURL
property.description: Configures the URL for external probe mode

property.name: DebugHistory
property.description: Controls the number of transactions saved in diagnostics mode.

property.name: DebugTrigger
property.description: The probe captures transactions that meet one or more of the conditions defined by the triggers. These triggers examine the direction or type of the message flow and examine the message for an XPath expression match. When a message meets one of these conditions, the transaction is captured in diagnostics mode and becomes part of the list of transactions that can be viewed.

property.name: WebGUIMode
property.description: When enabled, WebGUI extension functions are supported.

object.name: XMLFirewallService

property.name: Type
property.description: Specify the mode of the XML Firewall. The default is Dynamic Backend.

property.name: XMLManager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets, the caching of documents, and provides configuration constraints on the size and parsing depth of documents. You can enable streaming operation by configuring an XML Manager to use a Streaming Compile Option Policy. More than one firewall may use the same XML Manager. Select an existing XML Manager from the list to assign the Manager to this firewall. Click the + button to create a new XML Manager that is assigned to this firewall. A default Manager is used if you do not create one.

property.name: URLRewritePolicy
property.description: A URL Rewrite Policy applies the rules established in the named policy to rewrite the URL used by the client to connect to the service this firewall represents. This helps to mask the URL and location of the actual service. Select an existing URL rewrite policy from the list of available policies. Click the + button to create a new URL rewrite policy that is then assigned to this firewall.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this firewall. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the firewall. SSL Proxy profiles can be used in either client or server communications.

property.name: StylePolicy
property.description: Select an XML firewall processing policy to assign to the XML firewall. A Processing Policy establishes the actions taken on messages flowing through the firewall. Click the + button to create a new Policy. Select an existing Policy and click the ... button to edit the Policy.

property.name: MaxMessageSize
property.summary: The maximum size of a SOAP or XML message
property.description: Specifies the maximum size of a SOAP or XML message in kilobytes. If this value is 0, no limit is enforced.

property.name: RequestType
property.description: Characterizes the type of traffic that originates from the client. The default is SOAP.

property.name: ResponseType
property.description: Characterizes the type of traffic that originates from the server. The default is SOAP.

property.name: FWCred
property.description: Specifies an optional Firewall Credentials list for the XML firewall. A Firewall Credentials list specifies which keys and certificates are available to support firewall processing. In the absence of an identified Firewall Credentials list, all locally-stored key and certificates are available to the firewall.

property.name: ServiceMonitors
property.description: Specifies a list of Web Service Monitors for the firewall. Web Service Monitors target Web Service endpoints. Use the Web Services wizard on the Control Panel to supply a WSDL and configure a Monitor for an endpoint. The Monitor collects statistics, establishes count and duration monitors and can take action when thresholds are met or exceeded. A Monitor must be selected here to be activated. Click + to create a new Web Services Monitor. Note that this Monitor is not the Service Level Monitor (SLM) used by a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

property.name: RequestAttachments
property.summary: Attachment processing mode for client requests
property.description: Select how to treat client requests with attachments. The default is Strip.

property.name: ResponseAttachments
property.summary: Attachment processing mode for server responses
property.description: Select how to treat server responses with attachments. The default is Strip.

property.name: RootPartNotFirstAction
property.display: Action when required root part is not first
property.description: When streaming MIME messages, the action to take when the root part is not the first part of the message. If the root part must be first (for example to do BSP conformance checking) and the action is set to "process in order" the DP device will buffer attachments up to the root.

property.name: FrontAttachmentFormat
property.summary: Attachment processing format for client requests
property.description: Select how to interpret client requests with attachments. If an attachment arrives that is not of the type chosen, the attachment will be rejected.

property.name: BackAttachmentFormat
property.description: Select the attachment output format to backend servers. If an attachment arrives that is not of the type chosen, the attachment will be rejected.

description.p: The body of a message (that is, the payload, independent of any protocol headers) can sometimes contain MIME headers before any preamble and before the first MIME boundary contained in the body of the message. These MIME headers can contain important information not available in the protocol headers, such as the string identifying the MIME boundary. If this property is set to on, then these MIME headers will be processed by the Firewall.
Note that if this is on and there are no MIME headers contained in the message, the device will continue to try and parse the message, using the protocol header information, if available.

When this is off and MIME headers are present in the body of the message, these MIME headers will be considered part of the preamble and not used to parse out the message. If the protocol headers (such as HTTP) indicate the MIME boundaries, the device can parse and process individual attachments. If such information is not available, no attachments can be parsed from the body of the message.
