property.name: SOAPSchemaURL
property.summary: Specifies which W3C XML Schema will be used to validate SOAP documents
property.description: When a firewall is in SOAP mode, either on the request or response side, it will validate the incoming messages against a W3C Schema that defines what a SOAP message is supposed to look like. It is possible to customize which schema is used on a per-firewall basis by changing this property; this can be used to accomodate non-standard configurations or other special cases.

property.name: WSDLResponsePolicy
property.summary: Policy for responding to .NET WSDL requests
property.description: Select how the firewall handles requests for .NET WSDL requests via the http://domain.com/service?wsdl convention. The default is Off.

property.name: WSDLFileLocation
property.description: URL of the file to return when WSDL response policy is set to serve local.

property.name: FirewallParserLimits
property.summary: Use firewall parser limits instead of XML Manager parser limits.
property.description: Use the firewall parser limits instead of the parser limits in the XML Manager for this firewall. Firewall limits override XML Manager limits.

property.name: ParserLimitsBytesScanned
property.description: Defines the maximum number of bytes scanned by the XML parser. This applies to any XML document that is parsed. If any of the parser limits are set in the XML Firewall, they will override those on the XML Manager. If this value is 0, no limit is enforced.

property.name: ParserLimitsElementDepth
property.description: Defines the maximum depth of element nesting in XML parser. If any of the parser limits are set in the XML Firewall, they will override those on the XML Manager.

property.name: ParserLimitsAttributeCount
property.description: Defines the maximum number of attributes of a given element. If any of the parser limits are set in the XML Firewall, they will override those on the XML Manager.

property.name: ParserLimitsMaxNodeSize
property.description: Defines the maximum size any one node may consume. The default is 32 MB. Sizes which are powers of two result in the best performance. If any of the parser limits are set in the XML Firewall, they will override those on the XML Manager.

property.name: ParserLimitsForbidExternalReferences
property.summary: XML parser forbid external references toggle
property.description: Defines if the XML parser will abort when an input document specifies to resolve an external reference such as an external entity or external DTD definition.

property.name: ParserLimitsAttachmentByteCount
property.description: Defines the maximum number of bytes allowed in any single attachment. Attachments that exceed this size will result in a failure of the whole transaction. If this value is 0, no limit is enforced.

property.name: ParserLimitsAttachmentPackageByteCount
property.summary: Maximum cumulative byte count for all parts
property.description: Defines the maximum number of bytes allowed for all parts of an attachment package, including the root part. Attachment packages that exceed this size will result in a failure of the transaction. If this value is 0, no limit is enforced.

property.name: ParserLimitsExternalReferences
property.summary: Special handling for external references in XML
property.description: Select the special handling for input documents that contain external references, such as an external entity or external DTD definition.

property-group.name: monitors
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional Monitor settings

property-group.name: attachments
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional Attachment Processing settings

property-group.name: ProbeSettings
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional Probe settings
property-group.description:
The MultiStep Probe allows developers to view the changing value of variables and the changing contents of processing contexts. The developer can step through each action for any given transaction, up to a configured number of transactions. The Probe Settings page turns on this debugging tool and also sets the number of concurrently captured transactions.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

property-group.name: HTTPOptions
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional HTTP settings

object.description: Create or edit an XML Firewall on local IP/port (device address and port). This firewall may communicate with a dynamically identified server (or servers), a static back end server (at an identified remote IP/port) or as a loopback. The Firewall applies the selected processing policy to messages flowing through the firewall (request, response or both directions). Message content from client or server can be characterized as soap, xml, Non-XML (preprocessed) or Pass-Thru (unprocessed) and verified accordingly. The firewall may rewrite client request URLs using a URL rewrite policy. The firewall may use SSL communications to client, server or both directions if applicable.

object.name: XSLProxyService

property.name: Type
property.description: Specified the configuration mode for the XSL Proxy. The default is static-backend.

property.name: XMLManager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets, the caching of documents, and provides configuration constraints on the size and parsing depth of documents. More than one proxy may use the same XML Manager. Select an existing XML Manager from the list to assign the Manager to this XSL proxy. Click the + button to create a new XML Manager that is assigned to this proxy. A default Manager is used if you do not create one.

property.name: URLRewritePolicy
property.description: A URL Rewrite Policy applies the rules established in the named policy to rewrite the URL used by the client to connect to the service this proxy represents. This helps to mask the URL and location of the actual service. Select an existing URL rewrite policy from the list of available policies. Click the + button to create a new URL rewrite policy that is then assigned to this proxy.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this XSL proxy. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the XSL proxy. SSL Proxy profiles can be used in either client or server communications.

property.name: StylePolicy
property.description: Select an existing XSL proxy processing policy to assign to the XSL proxy. A Proxy Policy establishes the actions taken on messages flowing through the Proxy. Click the + button to create a new Policy. Select an existing Policy and click the ... button to edit an existing Policy.

property-group.name: monitors
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional Monitor settings

property-group.name: ProbeSettings
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional probe settings
property-group.description:
The MultiStep Probe allows developers to view the changing value of variables and the changing contents of processing contexts. The developer can step through each action for any given transaction, up to a configured number of transactions. The Probe Settings page turns on this debugging tool and also sets the number of concurrently captured transactions.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

property-group.name: HTTPOptions
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional HTTP settings

object.description: Creates an XSL Proxy on local IP/port for server on remote IP/port. A loopback proxy does not require a remote IP and port. The Proxy applies the selected XSL proxy processing policy to messages flowing through the proxy (as requests, responses or both directions). The proxy may apply the selected URL rewrite policy to client requests. If needed, the proxy may communicate with either the back end server or the requesting client using the SSL profiles selected.
Defines an HTTP Proxy Service.

object.name: HTTPService

property.name: Priority
property.description: Control the service scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority services will be favored over lower priority services.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 80) that specifies the port monitored by the HTTP server.

property.name: Mode
property.description: Selects the HTTP server mode. The default is Normal.

property.name: Identifier
property.description: This value is returned in the HTTP headers that Identify the HTTP Server.

property.name: BaseDir
property.description: Specify the local flash directory from which the server serves documents (including the Start Page). This value is typically "local:///" (note the triple slashes) or "store:///". If no Start Page file exists in this directory, the server will return an automatically generated index of the contents of the directory.

property.name: StartPage
property.description: Specify the page to display when the client first accesses the server. The HTML file has to be located in the configured base directory. If this is left blank, the server will return an automatically generated list of the contents of the Base Directory.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

object.description: Creates an HTTP server. This server delivers documents stored on the local system.

object.name: SSLProxyService

property.name: Priority
property.description: Control the service scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority services will be favored over lower priority services.

property.name: LocalPort
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535) that specifies the port monitored by the SSL proxy

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the remote peer for SSL communications.

property.name: RemotePort
property.description: Specify the port number of the remote peer for SSL communications.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an SSL Proxy Profile to manage SSL communications with the peer. The SSL Proxy Profile identifies the keys and certificates to use in the handshake.

object.description: Creates a SSL Proxy service (SSL forwarder). This service can be used by Log Targets to securely connect to a remote logging system.

object.name: TCPProxyService

property.name: Priority
property.description: Control the service scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority services will be favored over lower priority services.

property.name: LocalPort
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535) that specifies the port monitored by the TCP proxy

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the remote host for which this proxy is accepting TCP traffic. TCP traffic sent to the proxy will in turn be sent to this host. Click Ping to verify connectivity.

property.name: RemotePort
property.description: Specify the port number of the remote host, specify with Remote Host, for which this proxy is accepting TCP traffic.

object.description: Creates a TCP Proxy service.

object.name: XSLCoprocService

property.name: Priority
property.description: Control the service scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority services will be favored over lower priority services.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Enter the number of the local port monitored by by the XSL Coprocessor.

property.name: XMLManager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets, the caching of documents, and provides configuration constraints on the size and parsing depth of documents. You can enable streaming operation by configuring an XML Manager to use a Streaming Compile Option Policy. More than one coprocessor may use the same XML Manager. Select an existing XML Manager from the list to assign the Manager to this Coprocessor. Click the + button to create a new XML Manager that is assigned to this Coprocessor. A default Manager is used if you do not create one.

property.name: URLRewritePolicy
property.description: Select an existing URL Rewrite policy and assign the policy to the XSL Coprocessor, or create a new URL Rewrite policy and assign that rewrite policy to the XSL Coprocessor.

property.name: StylePolicyRule
property.description: Select an existing Processing Rule and assign the rule to the XSL Coprocessor, or select None (the default). When None is selected, the CoProcessor will use the stylesheet specified in the request. If the stylesheet is not cached on the device, the CoProcessor will call back and retrieve it from the requesting entity. To create a new Processing Rule and assign that Processing Rule to the XSL Coprocessor, click the + button. Select a rule and click the ... button to edit the rule.

property.name: ConnectionTimeout
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 3 through 7200, with a default of 60) that a XSL coproc maintains an idle connection.

property.name: IntermediateResultTimeout
property.description: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 1 through 600, with a default of 20) that a XSL coproc maintains an unused Intermediate Result nodeset.

property.name: CacheRelativeURL
property.summary: Enables caching of relative client URL
property.description: Configures the caching of relative client URL's. If enabled documents specified by relative URL's will be cached.

property.name: UseClientURIResolver
property.summary: Redirect external resource URL to client URI resolver
property.description: Configures the resolving of external resource URL's. If enabled external resources are resolved through the client URI resolver.

property.name: CryptoExtensions
property.description: Configures access to crypto extensions in referenced stylesheet rules. If enabled crypto extension functions can be used in multistep transformations.

property.name: DefaultParamNamespace
property.description: If a stylesheet parameter is defined without a namespace (or without explicitly specifying the null namespace), then this is the namespace into which the parameter will be assigned.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an existing SSL profile and assign the SSL profile to the XSL coproc, or create a new SSL profile and assign that SSL profile to the XSL coproc.

property.name: DebugMode
property.description: Select the diagnostic mode for processing policies. When enabled, the display includes the Probe button. The transactions captured by the probe can be used to view the state of variables and contexts for a captured transaction.

property.name: DebuggerType
property.description: Select the probe mode.

property.name: DebuggerURL
property.description: Configures the URL for external probe mode

property.name: DebugHistory
property.description:
Sets the number of transactions captured in diagnostics mode.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

property.name: DebugTrigger
property.description: The probe captures transactions that meet one or more of the conditions defined by the triggers. These triggers examine the direction or type of the message flow and examine the message for an XPath expression match. When a message meets one of these conditions, the transaction is captured in diagnostics mode and becomes part of the list of transactions that can be viewed.

property-group.name: ProbeSettings
property-group.summary: Click Tab to display optional Probe settings
property-group.description:
The MultiStep Probe allows developers to view the changing value of variables and the changing contents of processing contexts. The developer can step through each action for any given transaction, up to a configured number of transactions. The Probe Settings page turns on this debugging tool and also sets the number of concurrently captured transactions.
Note: The number of concurrent xml sessions is limited to the value of the transaction history size.

object.description: Creates an XSL Coprocessor. An XSL Coprocessor accepts input not from a client, as in XSL Proxy or XML Firewall operation, but from a Java program or a plug-in equipped application running on another machine on the local network. Messages are sent to the coprocessor by the Java library or plug-in, the Coprocessor then applies the Processing Rule selected and returns the result to the calling routine. When the Rule is set to None, the CoProcessor uses the XSL stylesheet supplied by the calling entity.

object.name: ShellAlias

property.name: command
property.description: Enter the sequence of commands to invoke. Use a semicolon to separate the commands. The macro invokes the commands in the specified sequence. For example, configure terminal; backup latest.zip appdomain.

object.description: Creates a user-defined macro that runs the specified sequence of commands when invoked from the command line. You can use the WebGUI to create and modify macros, but you can invoke these macros from the command line only.

object.name: SimpleCountMonitor

property.name: TPS
property.description: The rate of acceptable traffic, per user, expressed in transactions per second.

property.name: Action
property.description: Select the action to take when the rate limit is exceeded. The default is Reject.

property.name: MaxSources
property.description: The system organizes the counts user by the identity most recently used. When too many distinct counts have been observed, the users not seen in the longest time are discarded. This parameter specifies how many distinct users are tracked before discard.

property.name: ConcurrentConnections
property.description: The number of simultaneous connections allowed per user. Set to 0 to disable this enforcement.

object.description: A simple TPS based message monitor that limits the transaction rate any single user may achieve.

object.name: SLMAction

property.name: Type
property.description: Select the administrative procedure for the triggered SLM Action.

property.name: LogLevel
property.description: Specify the priority of the log message that is generated when a monitored messages type exceeds a threshold value.

object.description: An SLM Action defines the steps to take when an SLM policy statement detects a service level violation.

property.name: CredType
property.description: Select the method to use to obtain the credential value (the user identity) for each transaction.

property.name: CredMatchType
property.description: Select the matching algorithm to apply.

property.name: CredValue
property.description: Provide one or more values to match.

property.name: Stylesheet
property.description: When the credential type is custom-stylesheet, specify the XSL stylesheet URL.

property.name: Header
property.description: When the credential type is request-header, specify the name of the header.

description.p: An SLM Credential Class is used to select messages for inclusion in the SLM policy. A Credential Class obtains a credential (a user identity) from a message. Any one of the various Types of credentials may be selected from the message (see Credential Type below for specific information). The Type determines the method used to obtain the identity.

The Match Type setting determines the method used to match the credential obtained. If a match is made, the message is included in the set of messages affected by the SLM Policy. See Match Type below for specifics.

object.name: SLMPolicy

property.name: ExecutionPolicy
property.description: Select the operational behavior of the policy.

description.p: A Statement establishes criteria for selecting messages, sets a measurement interval, sets thresholds and determines the action to take when the threshold is met for the selected messages.
If no Credential Class is provided, this value is not used to select messages. By default, all messages are selected.
If no Resource Class is provided, this value is not used to select messages. By default, all messages are selected.
A Policy may have many statements. Statements execute in order according to the value of the Identifier field.

property.name: PeerGroup
property.description: An SLM Policy may be enforced across a group of devices handling load-balanced traffic destined for the same resources. A Peer Group establishes a data sharing protocol among these devices such that each device includes the traffic that has passed through the other peers when calculating whether or not a threshold has been reached.

object.description:
An SLM Policy counts messages or measures execution durations for messages passing through the device during a configured measurement window that match a set of selection criteria. The policy can take action when configured thresholds are reached.
For example, a policy may throttle all traffic arriving faster than 1000 messages per second for each click tick second. A policy may generate a log message for all messages arriving during the last elapsed second that originate from a given IP address and request the use of a given resource.
Messages are selected based on a Credential Class, a Resource Class, or both. If neither are configured, all messages are selected .
A policy consists of one or more Statements. Statements in turn establish the Credential Class, Resource Class, Thresholds and Actions to take when those thresholds are met.

property.name: RsrcType
property.description: Select the method to identify the requested resource.

property.name: RsrcMatchType
property.description: Select the matching algorithm to apply.

property.name: RsrcValue
property.description: Supply one or more values to match.

property.name: Stylesheet
property.description: When the resource type is custom-stylesheet, specify the XSL stylesheet.

property.name: XPathFilter
property.description: When the resource type is xpath-filter, specify the XPath filter.

property.name: Subscription
property.description: When the resource type is UDDI subscription, specify the subscription key.

property.name: WSRRSubscription
property.description: When the resource type is WSRR subscription, select the subscription.

description.p: An SLM Resource Class is used to select messages for inclusion in the SLM policy. A Resource Class obtains a resource identifier from a message. Any one of the various Types of resources may be selected from the message (see Resource Type below for specific information). The Type determines the method used to obtain the resource.

The Match Type setting determines the method used to match the resource obtained. If a match is made, the message is included in the set of messages affected by the SLM Policy. See Match Type below for specifics.

object.name: SLMSchedule

property.name: DaysOfWeek
property.summary: Days of the Week included in this schedule
property.description: Select the days of the week that are included in this SLM schedule. The Time and Duration apply to all selected days.

property.name: StartTime
property.summary: Time this schedule takes effect in 24 hour time (hh:mm:ss) in the current timezone.
property.description: Set the time at which this schedule takes effect. All times are expressed in 24 hour time (1 pm is 13:00:00).

property.name: Duration
property.summary: Length of this shedule in minutes. The minimum accepted value is 1 and the maximum is 1439. The default is 1439 (1 minute less than 1 day).

object.description: An SLM Schedule restricts the hours and days of operation of a SLM Policy statement. Schedules allow the application of different policies during different clock hours of a 24 hour day.

object.name: SNMPSettings

property.name: Version
property.description: Specifies the running SNMP software version. The default is version 2c.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.summary: IP address monitored for incoming SNMP requests
property.description: A specific IP address monitored by the SNMP agent or engine for incoming SNMP requests. The default value of 0.0.0.0 allows the agent or engine to listen on all interfaces. Selecting the address of one interface restricts SNMP to that interface.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: UDP port monitored for incoming SNMP requests
property.description: A specific UDP port monitored by the SNMP agent or engine for incoming SNMP requests. By default, the agent or engine monitors port 161.

property.name: Policies
property.summary: Define access policies for SNMPv1 and SNMPv2c by communities, and their mapping to an application domain.

property.name: Targets
property.summary: Specify SNMP Trap and Notification recipients

property.name: Users
property.description: The name of a user (which must have SNMP credential parameters) which is authorized to use SNMPv3 to access the MIBs on this system.

property.name: Contexts
property.summary: Create non-default SNMPv3 contexts, and define their mapping to an application domain. The default (empty string) context is always mapped to the default application domain.
property.description: SNMPv3 context definitions, which provide SNMPv3 access to non-default application domains.

property.name: SecurityLevel
property.summary: Set minimum security level required for incoming SNMPv3 requests.
property.description: The minimum security level required for incoming SNMPv3 Get and Set requests. The default is Authentication, Privacy.

property.name: AccessLevel
property.summary: Set limits on MIB access for incoming SNMPv3 requests.
property.description: The type of access allowed to MIB objects for incoming SNMPv3 Get and Set requests.

property.name: TrapPriority
property.description: Select a mininum trap event priority. The priorities are hierarchical. The lowest is listed last. Set to the minimum that is required for your trap events.

property.name: TrapEventCode
property.description: The list of event codes generating traps. You can add event codes which will be triggering traps send to the configured trap targets.

property.name: ConfigMib
property.summary: Provides a link to the DataPower Enterprise Configuration MIB.

property.name: StatusMib
property.summary: Provides a link to the DataPower Enterprise Status MIB.

property.name: NotifMib
property.summary: Provides a link to the DataPower Enterprise Notification MIB.

object.description: Use this page to establish SNMP connectivity to the device, and to set values used by SNMP.

description.p: Specify the directory to poll. The path must end in a slash. The path denotes a directory.
FTP examples:

ul.li:
Absolute to root directory: "ftp://user:password@host:port/@2Fpath/"
If the user name or password contains the characters ":", "@", or "/", use their URL-encoded values in accordance with the specification.
Relative to home directory of the user: "ftp://user:password@host:port/path/"

description.p:
NFS example:
"dpnfs://static-mount-name/path/"

Do not configure one poller to point at a host name that is a virtual name of a load balancer group. This configuration is not the correct way to poll multiple hosts. To poll multiple hosts, use the same DataPower service and configure one poller object for each real host.

Enter the number of milliseconds to wait after the completion of one poll sequence before starting the next one. A polling sequence is the actual polling action plus the time to complete all transactions that were started by the poll action. The next polling action will start the specified number of milliseconds after the last transaction completes.
Defaults to 60,000 (1 minute). Valid range 25 milliseconds to 100,000 milliseconds.

property.name: InputFileMatchPattern
property.summary: File name pattern to base poll search criteria.

description.p: Enter the PCRE to use to match the contents of the directory being polled. If there is file-renaming or there is a response, this PCRE must create PCRE back references using () pairs.
For example, if the input files are NNNNNN.input , the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" .

property.name: ProcessingRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that is being processed.

description.p: Enter the PCRE to use to rename a file that is being processed. This functionality allows multiple pollers to poll the same directory with the same match pattern. There is no lack of atomity if the rename operation on the server is atomic. The poller that succeeds in renaming the input file will proceed to process the file. Any other poller that tries to rename the file at the same time will fail to rename the file and will proceed to try the next file that matches the specified match pattern.
To ensure uniqueness, the resulting file name will be in the following format:
filename . serial . domain . poller . timestamp

where:
filename
The file name for the renamed input file.
serial
The serial number of the configured DataPower device.
domain
The domain of the polling object.
poller
The name of the polling object.
timestamp
The timestamp
Note: File renaming cannot be used with an FTP server that supports only 8.3 file names.

For example if the input files are NNNNNN.input and you want to rename them to NNNNNN.processing , then the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the processing pattern would be "$1.processing" . The resultant file name on the server would be:

Note: If no processing rename pattern is configured, the file will still be renamed. The only difference is that the filename portion of the resulting file is the name of the original input file, not the renamed input file.

property.name: DeleteOnSuccess
property.summary: Delete an input file after successful processing.

description.p: Select whether to delete the input file after successful processing. When on , deletes the input file. When off , renames the input file using the renaming pattern specified by Success File Renaming Pattern.

property.name: SuccessRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that has been processed successfully.

description.p: When Delete File on Success is off, enter the PCRE to use to rename the input file on success. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are NNNNNN.input and you want to rename them to NNNNNN.processed , the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the rename pattern would be "$1.processed" .

Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be "(.*)" and the rename pattern would be "../processed/$1" .

property.name: DeleteOnError
property.summary: Delete a file after failure to process.

description.p: Select whether to delete the input or processing rename file when it could not be processed. When on , deletes the file. When off , renames the input or processing rename file using the renaming pattern specified by Error File Renaming Pattern.

property.name: ErrorRenamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to rename a file that could not be processed.

description.p: When Delete File on Processing Error is off , enter the PCRE to use to rename a file when it could not be processed.

property.name: GenerateResultFile
property.summary: Create a result file after processing an input file.

description.p: Select whether to create a result file after processing an input file. When on , creates the result file using the naming pattern specified by Result File Name Pattern. When off , does not create the result file.

property.name: ResultNamePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to build the name of a response file.

description.p: When Generate Result File is on, enter the PCRE to use as the match pattern to build the name of the result file. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are NNNNNN.input and the desired result file name is NNNNNN.result , then the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the result pattern would be "$1.result" .

Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be "(.*)" and the result pattern would be "../result/$1" .

property.name: ProcessingSeizeTimeout
property.summary: Time to wait before processing a file that is already in processing state.

description.p: Enter the time to wait, in seconds, before processing a file that is already in the processing state. Defaults to 0 (disabled). Valid range is 0 through 1000.

Processing seize allows failure handling of a poller when multiple data routers are polling the same target. If another data router renames a file and does not process (and rename or delete) it within the specified number of seconds, this system attempts to take over processing. This system will attempt to take over processing when all of these three conditions are met when compared to the processing seize pattern.
The base file name (first match phrase) is the processing seize pattern
The host name (second match phrase) is not the name of this system
The timestamp (third match phrase) is further in the past than the wait time specified by this timeout
When these three conditions are met, this system renames the file (with its host name and fresh timestamp) and locally processes the file. This processing assumes that the rename succeeded.

property.name: ProcessingSeizePattern
property.summary: File name pattern used to find files being processed.

description.p: Enter the PCRE to use to find files that were renamed to indicate that they are in the “being processed” state but the processing was never completed.

The processing seize pattern contains three phrases that must be in "()" pairs. The first phrase is the base file name that includes the configured processing suffix. The second phrase is the host name. The third phrase is the timestamp.
For example: "(.*).processing.([^.]*).([0-9]*)" . This assumes that "$1.processing" was supplied as the Processing File Renaming Pattern.

property.name: XMLManager
property.description: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets and documents. The XML Manager can also control the size and depth of messages processed by this host. Select an existing XML Manager from the list or click the + button to create a new XML Manager to assign to this host. More than one service may use the same XML Manager.

object.name: FTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler
object.description: Use this front side option to have file based input from a configured FTP directory. The directory must exist and have the appropriate permission to perform the designated operations. For these configured directories, ensure that the read, write, and delete permissions are available, as required.

object.name: NFSFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler
object.description: Use this front side option to have file based input from an NFS mount. The mount point must exist and have the appropriate permissions to perform the designated operations. For these configured mount points, ensure that the read, write, and delete permissions are available, as required.

description.p: Enter the address on which the FTP server service listens. The default of 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases can help ease migration tasks among machines. For more information, see the Host Alias section in the Network Objects chapter.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: Local TCP port for the FTP server

description.p: Enter the port that is monitored by the FTP Server service. This port is the port on which FTP control connections can be established. This port does not control the TCP port that is used for the data connections. If the FTP client uses the PASV command, data connections will use an arbitrary, unused TCP port. Defaults to 21. Valid range is 1 through 65535.

property.name: FilesystemType
property.summary: The type of filesystem the FTP server will present

description.p: Select the file system type that is presented by the FTP server.

If Virtual Ephemeral or Virtual Persistent is chosen, the client can write files to all directories. These files are shown in directory listings but cannot be retrieved. For file system responses, the responses are shown and can be retrieved, renamed, and deleted by the client.
If Transparent is chosen, the file system shows the contents of the equivalent path of the server on the back-end of the Multi-Protocol Gateway with which this FTP server is associated.

property.name: PersistentFilesystemTimeout
property.summary: Controls how long a Virtual Persistent file system with no active connections is retained
property.description: Enter the duration in seconds that a connection to a virtual file system is retained after all FTP control connections from user identities are disconnected. When the timeout expires, the virtual file system object is destroyed. All of the response files that were not deleted by the FTP client are deleted from their storage area. Default to 600 (10 minutes). Valid range is 1 to 43,200 seconds (12 hours).

property.name: VirtualDirectories
property.summary: Create directory in virtual file system of FTP server
property.description: In virtual mode, create a directory in the virtual file system that is presented by this FTP server. The FTP client can use all of these directories to write file to be processed. The root directory (/) is always present and cannot be created. Its response directory is always the root directory.

property.name: DefaultDirectory
property.description: Enter the initial working directory on the FTP server (after users connect and authenticate). When using a virtual file system and the working directory is not the root directory, the specified directory must be one of the configured virtual directories. The default is the root directory (/).

property.name: MaxFilenameLength
property.summary: Maximum length of a file name on the server
property.description: Enter the maximum file name length on the FTP server. Defaults to 256 characters. Valid range is 1 through 4000.

description.p: Select an Access Control List to apply. The ACL allows or denies access to the FTP server based on the IP address of the FTP client. When attached to a server, the default for an ACL is to deny all access. To deny access to only select IP addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0). Then, create deny entries for the desired hosts.

To create a new ACL, click the + button. To edit an ACL, click the … button. Note that if an ACL object with the same name as this Handler exists, the system might inadvertently use that ACL rather than the one selected here.

property.name: RequireTLS
property.summary: Control whether FTP control connections require TLS encryption

description.p: Specify whether FTP control connections require explicit TLS encryption. If required, the FTP client must use the FTP AUTH TLS command before any other command. This setting does not control encryption of data transfers.
If required, the FTP client must use the FTP AUTH TLS command before any other command.
Note: This property does not control encryption of data transfers. Data Transfers are controlled by the File Transfer Data Encryption property.

Control support of SSL/TLS encryption by this FTP server. If an SSL Proxy Profile is assigned, the FTP AUTH TLS server command will be enabled, and the client will be able to start SSL/TLS encryption of the FTP control connection.

The chosen SSL Proxy Profile controls the SSL/TLS credentials that the FTP server will present to the client after the AUTH TLS command, and how the SSL/TLS credentials presented by the client will be evaluated.
To create a new SSL Proxy Profile, click the + button. To edit an existing SSL Proxy Profile, click the … button.

property.name: PasswordAAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA policy for validating user name and password

description.p: Selects the AAA Policy to perform authentication of user names and passwords provided to the FTP server by the client with the USER and PASS commands. If the authentication succeeds, the FTP client may use all the features of the FTP server. If the authentication fails, a 530 error is returned, and the user can attempt to authenticate again. Without this AAA Policy configured, any user name and password will be accepted.
To create a new AAA Policy, click the + button. To edit an AAA Policy, click the … button.

property.name: CertificateAAAPolicy
property.summary: AAA Policy for determining whether password is required

description.p: Selects the AAA Policy to perform secondary authentication of the information provided in the TLS/SSL certificate provided during TLS negotiation after the AUTH TLS command to the FTP server. Primary authentication is done by the SSL Profile, it can completely reject a certificate. This authentication stage controls whether an FTP password will be demanded or not. If the result of this authentication succeeds, the FTP client will only have to use the USER command to login after the AUTH TLS . If this authentication fails, the FTP client will have to use both the USER and PASS commands to complete the login process. If no Certificate AAA Policy is configured, USER and PASS will always be required. If the AUTH TLS command is not used by the FTP client, USER and PASS will always be required.
To create a new AAA Policy, click the + button. To edit an AAA Policy, click the … button.

Specify whether the FTP CCC command can be used to turn off TLS encryption of the FTP control connection after user authentication. If allowed, the CCC command can be used to turn off encryption after authentication. Turning off encryption is necessary when the FTP control connection crosses a firewall or NAT device that needs to sniff the control connection. Turning off encryption eliminates the secrecy of the files being transferred and allows TCP packets injection attacks.

property.name: Passive
property.description: Control use of the FTP PASV and EPSV commands by the FTP client, as an alternative to the PORT and EPRT commands. The default is to allow PORT, EPRT, PASV, and EPSV. Other settings either require PASV or EPSV, or require PORT or EPRT. If an acceptable PORT, EPRT, PASV, or EPSV command is not received, the STOR, STOU, RETR, LIST, and NLST data transfer commands will fail. (This FTP server will never attempt to connect to the deprecated default FTP data port at TCP port 20.)

property.name: UsePasvPortRange
property.display: Limit Port Range for Passive Connections
property.summary: Enable using a limited range of TCP port numbers for Passive connections.

description.p: When enabled, when a PASV or EPSV command is received from the FTP client, instead of selecting any free listening TCP port in the range 1024 to 65534, allow configuration of a restricted port range. This may be used when a firewall wants to allow incoming FTP data connections only on a limited range of ports, particularly when it cannot "sniff" the FTP control connection.

Note that the size of the range specified limits how many FTP clients can be in the state between receiving the 227 response code to the PASV or EPSV command, and establishing the FTP data TCP connection. Pressure on this limited resource can be controlled by adjusting the passive data connection idle timeout.

While it is perfectly legal to configure multiple FTP servers on the same system to use the same (or overlapping) passive port ranges, realize that they are contending for a common resource in the TCP implementation.

However, it is not wise to use a port range that overlaps with other services (HTTP servers, etc.) configured on the system. There is no configuration checking for such conflicts, and other configured services will allocate the ports first, and they will not be available for the FTP server. (The FTP server allocates these listing ports dynamically.)

property.name: PasvMinPort
property.summary: Lowest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the lowest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not greater than Maximum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvMaxPort
property.summary: Highest port value for the passive port range
property.description: Specify the highest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Any value from 1024 to 65534 is valid, as long as this not less than Minimum Passive Port.

property.name: PasvIdleTimeOut
property.summary: Passive Data Connection Idle Timeout in seconds.

description.p: Specify the amount of time between when the FTP server issues a 227 response to a PASV or EPSV command from the FTP client, and when the FTP client must establish a data TCP connection to the listening port and issue a data transfer command.

If a FTP data TCP connection is not established within the timeout period, the listening port will be closed. If a data transfer command (STOR, STOU, RETR, LIST, or NLST) has been issued, it will fail with a result code of 425, with the message "failed to open data connection". If the data connection has not been issued, it will treated as if the PASV or EPSV command was never issued, return a result code of 425, with the message "require PASV or PORT command first".

If a FTP data TCP connection is established, but no data transfer command is issued before the timeout period expires, the TCP connection will be closed. Any data transfer command after the timeout will be treated as if the PASV or EPSV command was never issued.
The default timeout is 60 seconds, the allowable range is 5 to 300 seconds.

property.name: DataEncryption
property.summary: Control use of data encryption for file transfers
property.description: Select the use of encryption for data connections (file transfers). Data encryption is controlled by the FTP PROT P command.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.summary: Control use of MODE Z command to compress data transfer

description.p: Specify whether the FTP client can use FTP MODE Z compression. After enabling FTP compression, the FTP client can use the zlib method to compress data transfers.

property.name: AllowSTOU
property.summary: Control use of STOU command for unique file names

description.p: Specify whether the FTP client can use the FTP STOU command. When enabled, the FTP server generates a unique file name for each transferred file.

property.name: UniqueFilenamePrefix
property.summary: Prefix of all unique filenames generated by STOU

description.p: Enter the prefix (leading characters) for file names that are generated when using the FTP STOU command. When defining the prefix, the directory separator (/) is not allowed. The default is to not add a prefix, which is an empty string.
The format is ^[^/]*$
Note: The software adds a numeric suffix.

property.name: AllowREST
property.summary: Control use of the REST command for interrupted file transfers

description.p: Controls whether the FTP client can use the FTP REST command to continue the transfer of a file after an interruption in the data transfer. This is supported in the BSD stream style described in draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt. (The MODE B style that is described in RFC 959 is not supported.) The FTP server must be configured with a virtual persistent file system.

For written files, the server will delay the actual processing until a timeout expires or until the next FTP command other than a SIZE or REST command. This processing allows the FTP client can return and resume to the transfer using the SIZE , REST , and STOR commands. The argument to the REST command must be the same as the byte count returned by the SIZE command.
Note: The response code to all STOR commands on this server will always be 226. The response codes does not reflect the success of the transaction.
This capability is also supported for reading the response files, if the server is configured for a Response Type of Virtual Filesystem.
Note: The generation of response files are delayed until the transaction is completed.

property.name: RestartTimeout
property.summary: Time that the STOR command waits for a restart

description.p: When restart ( REST ) is enabled, the number of seconds that the FTP client has to reconnect to the server and use the SIZE , REST , and STOR commands to continue an interrupted file transfer. If this period of time elapses, the data that was received to this point on the TCP data connection will be passed to the Multi-Protocol Gateway. This timeout is canceled if another command (other than SIZE or REST ) is received on the FTP control connection.

property.name: IdleTimeout
property.summary: Inactivity limit on FTP control connection
property.description: Enter the number of seconds that the FTP control connection can be idle. After the specified duration elapses, the FTP server closes the control connection. Defaults to 0, which disables the timeout.

property.name: ResponseType
property.summary: How to make response available to FTP client
property.description: Select how to make response files available for gateway transactions started by an FTP STOR or SOUT operation.

property.name: ResponseStorage
property.description: Select where response files are stored.

property.name: TemporaryStorageSize
property.summary: Maximum size of temporary file system
property.description: Enter in megabytes the maximum size for the temporary file system size. Defaults to 32 MB. Valid range is 1 MB through 2048 MB.

property.name: ResponseNFSMount
property.summary: NFS mount to store response files in

description.p: When Response Type is Virtual File System and Response Storage is NFS, select an NFS static mount to apply. Each response file will have a unique file name in the NFS directory. The name of the response file is not related to the file name that the virtual file system presents to the FTP client. Generally, this NFS directory is not made available through the FTP server. This directory should not be used for any other purpose.
To create a new NFS static mount, click the + button. To edit an NFS static mount, click the … button.

property.name: ResponseSuffix
property.summary: URL file name suffix to response file

description.p: When Response Type is Virtual File System or FTP Client, enter the suffix to add when generating response files. The directory separator (/) is not allowed. The suffix should be in the ^[^/]*$ format. Defaults to an empty string.

property.name: ResponseURL
property.summary: URL for generating a response via FTP client

description.p: When Response Type is FTP Client, enter the URL to use when generating response files. This URL enables a response to be written using FTP commands. The URL must be an FTP URL that starts with ftp:// . The URL should include a directory, but not a file name. The URL cannot include query parameters. The URL should be in the ^ftp://[^/]+(/[^/]+)*$ format. The default is to have no response generated (an empty string).
The FTP Server Front Side Handler provides an FTP server that can be used to submit files for processing by the system. Each file that is written results in one transaction.
There can be multiple FTP servers, but only one server can listen on the default port 21 on a given IP address. There can be multiple simultaneous connections from FTP clients to the same FTP server.

ul.li: The 226 FTP response code at the end of an FTP STOR or FTP STOU command is conditional on successful completion of the internal steps and backside operation of the transaction.
Changes in the configuration affect only new connections to this FTP server. Existing connections continue to use their current configuration until they disconnect.

object.name: HTTPSourceProtocolHandler

property.name: LocalAddress
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 80) that specifies the port monitored by the HTTP service.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.description: Select the HTTP version to use on the front (client) side connection. The default is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: AllowedFeatures
property.summary: Request methods and versions must be of only the allowed types
property.description: Specifies the allowed methods and versions for incoming HTTP requests.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Enable/Disable persistent connections on front side
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression functionality on front side.

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted
property.description: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted in bytes. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum Aggregate Size of Incoming Headers
property.description: The maximum aggregate byte size of incoming HTTP headers.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.display: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.summary: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.description: The maximum number of headers allowed in the request message. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the name portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the value portion of that header. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxQueryStringLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.description: The portion of the URL after a ? is known as the query string. This property specifies its maximum length in bytes. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

object.description: The configuration for a front side HTTP protocol handler. This handler receives HTTP requests sent to the device and forwards them to the appropriate gateway. It conforms to gateway specifications of RFC 2616.

object.name: HTTPSSourceProtocolHandler

property.name: LocalAddress
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 443) that specifies the port monitored by the HTTPS service.

property.name: HTTPVersion
property.description: Select the HTTP version to use on the front (client) side connection. The default is HTTP 1.1.

property.name: AllowedFeatures
property.summary: Request methods and versions must be of only the allowed types
property.description: Specifies the allowed methods and versions for incoming HTTP requests.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Enable/Disable persistent connections on front side
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: AllowCompression
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression functionality on front side.

property.name: MaxURLLen
property.summary: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted
property.description: The longest incoming URL that will be accepted in bytes. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier.

property.name: MaxTotalHdrLen
property.summary: Maximum Aggregate Size of Incoming Headers
property.description: The maximum aggregate byte size of incoming HTTP headers.

property.name: MaxHdrCount
property.display: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.summary: Maximum Number of HTTP Request Headers Allowed
property.description: The maximum number of headers allowed in the request message. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxNameHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Name
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the name portion of that header.0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxValueHdrLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Header Value
property.description: Each HTTP Header is expressed as a name and value pair. This property specifies the maximum length of the value portion of that header.0 means unlimited.

property.name: MaxQueryStringLen
property.display: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.summary: Maximum Allowed Length of HTTP Query String
property.description: The portion of the URL after a ? is known as the query string. This property specifies its maximum length in bytes. 0 means unlimited.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this handler. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the firewall.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

object.description: The configuration for a front side HTTPS protocol handler. This handler receives HTTP requests sent to the device over SSL and forwards them to the appropriate gateway. It conforms to gateway specifications of RFC 2616.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 3000) that specifies the port monitored by the stateful raw XML over TCP service.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this handler. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the firewall.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Enable/Disable persistent connections on front side
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: EBCDICInput
property.description: Indicates if input headers are in EBCDIC or ASCII. Note that payload is not automatically processed.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

description.p: Description goes here...
Enter the name of the GET queue associated with the WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS object supported by this protocol handler.

The WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS Front Side Handler monitors the GET queue for incoming client requests. Upon message receipt, the handler forwards the extracted message to the supported WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS object that will gateway the message to a remote WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS message provider.
Enter the name of the PUT queue associated with the WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS object supported by this protocol handler.
The PUT queue contains server-originated WAS JMS or TIBCO EMS reply messages.
Such messages are originated by a remote WAS JMS or TIBCO EMS message provider and put into this queue by a local WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS object.
Configuration of a PUT queue is optional.
A PUT queue should be configured if server replies are expected; if reply messages are not expected, a PUT queue need not be configured.
In the absence of a PUT queue, any received replies are dropped.
Provide an SQL-like expression to filter messages from the GET queue.
For example:

This expression specifies that only client requests that have a DeliveryMode of PERSISTENT are forwarded to the WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS object for processing; all other messages are dropped from the GET queue.

The message selector is a conditional expression based on a subset of SQL92 conditional expression syntax. The conditional expression enables the WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS Front Side Handler to identify messages of interest .

The conditional expression does not operate on the body of the JMS or EMS message, rather it examines JMS or EMS message headers and properties (proprietary user-created headers that might appear between the required headers and the message body).
The required JMS and EMS headers are as follows:
contains the destination (queue) to which the message is being sent
contains the delivery mode (PERSISTENT or NON_PERSISTENT)
contains a message TTL or a value of 0 indicating an unlimited TTL
contains the message priority expressed as a digit from 0 (lowest priority) to 9 (highest priority)
contains a unique message identifier starting with the prefix ID:, or a null value, effectively disabling message ID
contains the time the message was handed off for transmission, not the time it was actually sent
contains a means of associating one message (for example, a response) with another message (for example, the original request)
contains the destination (queue) to which a reply to this message should be sent
contains a message identifier provided by the application
contains a boolean indicating that the message has been delivered in the past, but not yet acknowledged

Configuration of a message selector is optional. If a message selector is not specified, all incoming client request messages are transferred by the WebSphere JMS or TIBCO EMS Front Side Handler to the WebSphere JMS object or TIBCO EMS object for processing.

property.name: Server
property.description: Select a server from the list of available TIBCO EMS servers

description.p: Identify the WebSphere JMS server object supported by this protocol handler.
Select a server object from the list of available objects.
If necessary, you can use the + button to create a new WebSphere JMS server object, or the ... button to edit an existing object.

property.name: RequestTopicSpace
property.display: WebSphere JMS Topic Space for Request
property.summary: WebSphere JMS Topic Space for Request

description.p: Use this property to disambiguate a topic if the request destination is a topic whose name appears in multiple topic spaces.

A topic space is a hierarchy of topics used for publish/subscribe messaging. Topics with the same name can exist in multiple topic spaces, but there can be only one topic space with a given name in a service integration bus.
For example, consider a topic hierarchy split into the following topic spaces:

ul.li: library - topics for document management
sales - topics for marketing and sales tracking
engineering - topics for engineering and technology

description.p: The topic volumes can appear in all three topic spaces, and have a different meaning in each.
Enter the name of the target topic space if necessary.

property.name: ReplyTopicSpace
property.display: WebSphere JMS Topic Space for Reply
property.summary: WebSphere JMS Topic Space for Reply

description.p: Use this property to disambiguate a topic if the response destination is a topic whose name appears in multiple topic spaces.

A topic space is a hierarchy of topics used for publish/subscribe messaging. Topics with the same name can exist in multiple topic spaces, but there can be only one topic space with a given name in a service integration bus.
For example, consider a topic hierarchy split into the following topic spaces:

ul.li: library - topics for document management
sales - topics for marketing and sales tracking
engineering - topics for engineering and technology

description.p: The topic volumes can appear in all three topic spaces, and have a different meaning in each.
Enter the name of the target topic space if necessary.

property.name: QueueManager
property.summary: An MQ Queue Manager object name
property.description: Select a Queue Manager from the list of available Queue Managers

property.name: GetQueue
property.description: Enter the name of the GET queue associated with the identified Queue Manager. The Handler will get messages from this queue.

property.name: PutQueue
property.description: Enter the name of the PUT queue associated with the identified Queue Manager. The Handler will put messages to this queue.

property.name: CodePage
property.description: For MQCCSI_EMBEDDED enter 4294967295; for MQCCSI_INHERIT enter 4294967294

property.name: GetMessageOptions
property.summary: Options flags for the MQGMO structure
property.description: Specifies the cumulative value of the MQGET options that are applicable to an MQ message in decimal or hexadecimal format. The value is passed directly to the MQ API. The default is 4097 (decimal value for the MQGMO_WAIT and the MQGMO_SYNCPOINT_IF_PERSISTENT options).

property.name: ExcludeHeaders
property.description: Select which headers after MQMD to strip from the message. By default only the MQMD header is parsed.

property.name: ConcurrentConnections
property.display: The number of concurrent MQ connections
property.summary: The number of concurrent MQ connections allocated for this source protocol handler
property.description: The number of concurrent MQ connections allocated for this source protocol handler. The default value is 1, but it can be increased to improve performance.

property.name: PollingInterval
property.summary: The number of seconds before MQGET operation returns if no messages are available.
property.description: The number of seconds before MQGET operation returns if no messages are available, the next attempt will be performed immediately. Setting this value to minimum will help to detect quickly network connectivity issues and queue manager power shutdown but at the same time will increase network traffic.

property.name: ContentTypeHeader
property.summary: MQ Header to extract Content-Type with XPath expression
property.description: MQ Header to extract Content-Type with XPath expression.

property.name: ContentTypeXPath
property.display: XPath expression to extract Content-Type from MQ header
property.summary: XPath expression to extract Content-Type from MQ header
property.description: XPath expression to extract Content-Type from MQ header

property.name: RetrieveBackoutSettings
property.summary: Controls retrieval of backout settings from the MQ server

description.p: Controls whether to retrieve backout setting from the MQ server.

When enabled, retrieves the Backout Threshold and Backout Requeue Queue Name settings from the MQ server and compares these values to the backout values for the MQ Queue Manager object. On retry, the handler uses the higher priority backout settings. If MQ server does not contain backout settings, the handler uses existing backout values, either empty or populated, from the MQ Queue Manager object. If the MQ Queue Manager object does not define backout values, this capability is disabled.
When disabled, the default, does not retrieve backout settings from the MQ server. If these properties already exist in the MQ Queue Manager object, the handler use those values.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 4000) that specifies the port monitored by the service.

property.name: PersistentConnections
property.summary: Enable/Disable persistent connections on front side
property.description: Toggle to enable or disable persistent connections where appropriate on front side.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this handler. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the front side..

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

description.p: The configuration for the stateless TCP protocol handler. This protocol uses raw XML - where the close of the root node delineates the document - PI's and comments outside of the root node are not allowed.

property.name: LocalAddress
property.description: The address on which the service listens. The default of 0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases help to ease migration tasks between machines. See Local Host Alias under Networking for more.

property.name: LocalPort
property.summary: The local TCP port number that supports server operations
property.description: An integer (within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 3000) that specifies the port monitored by the stateful raw XML over TCP service.

property.name: RemoteAddress
property.description: Specify the host name or IP address of the backend stateful TCP server.

property.name: RemotePort
property.description: Specify the remote TCP port number of the backend stateful TCP server.

property.name: CloseOnFault
property.description: If enabled, both the front and back TCP connections are closed when the DataPower device generates a fault; otherwise only a connection termination, timeout, or error closes the session.

property.name: SSLProxy
property.description: Select an existing SSL proxy profile from the list to assign the SSL proxy profile to this handler. Click the + button to create a new SSL proxy profile and assign that SSL proxy profile to the firewall.

property.name: ACL
property.description: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

description.p: The configuration for the stateful TCP protocol handler. This protocol uses raw XML - where the close of the root node delineates the document - PI's and comments outside of the root node are not allowed. The source protocol also specifies the destination address and any single TCP connection will use the same TCP session on the backside for all of its transactions (one transaction per document).
Any Gateway that employs one of these Handlers must use a Dynamic Backend.

object.name: Statistics

property.name: LoadInterval
property.description: The load interval may have a minimum of 500 msec and a maximum of 5000 msec.

object.description: Use this page to establish Statistics settings. Statistics must be enabled for some of the monitors to work correctly.

object.name: StylePolicy

property.name: UserSummary
property.description: Enter a comment. This appears on the Policy catalog page.

property.name: DefStylesheetForSoap
property.summary: Identify the default stylesheet used for SOAP filtering.
property.description: Identify the default stylesheet used for SOAP filtering. The default rejects all SOAP documents.

property.name: DefStylesheetForXsl
property.summary: Identify the default stylesheet used for XSL transformation
property.description: Identify the default stylesheet used for XSL transformation. The default mirrors all documents.

property.name: PolicyMaps
property.description: A list of processing rules their corresponding matching rule that this policy will evaluate. If a match is found, the corresponding processing rule is run. The policy runs the first processing rule with a successful match. Therefore, the order of rules in this list is important.

object.description: Create, Edit or Delete a Processing Policy. A policy consists of one or more Processing Rules. Rules execute depending upon the direction of the message and on whether or not a corresponding matching rule selects the document for processing. A service may have only one policy active at a time. Click Services in the left-hand navigation menu and then click the appropriate policy link to use the graphical interface to create and edit policies.

object.name: StylePolicyAction

property.name: Type
property.description: Select an action to be performed by the processing rule. The default is Transform.

property.name: Input
property.description:
Input identifies the context that contains the document acted upon by this action. Enter either the context name, the string PIPE, used for streaming execution mode, or the string INPUT which identifies the original input into this policy rule.
Not used when the action type is fetch, rewrite, or route-set and otherwise required.

property.name: Transform
property.description: Specify the location of the XSL stylesheet to use for document filtering or transformations. Specify the location as either a URL or as a variable that expands to a URL. If a variable, use the var://context/name form.

description.p: Enter the URL of the WTX map file for the transform. You must create the WTX map file by exporting the file from Design Studio. The WTX-generated map file must be uploaded to this location. When the file is on the appliance, use a string in the <directory>:///<filename> format.
Do not specify a Processing Control File when using a WTX map file.

property.name: TxTopLevelMap
property.summary: Name of the map to run
property.description: Enter the name of the specific map in the map file for the transform. A map file might contain more than one map. When this field is left blank, the transform uses the first map in the file.

property.name: TxMode
property.summary: Mode in which to run the map
property.description: Select the mode in which to run the map. DPA is the recommended mode.

property.name: Output
property.description:
Output identifies the destination context -- the context that receives the document upon completion of the specified action. Enter either the context name, the string PIPE, used for streaming execution mode (except for the last action), or the string OUTPUT which identifies the final input output from this policy rule. Depending on the rule's direction, OUTPUT specifies transmission to either the requesting client or responding server. If the action type is results, and no Output is specified, the target context is transmitted to OUTPUT.
Required when the action type is convert-http, cryptobin, extract, fetch, xform, xformbin, or xformpi. Optional when the action type is results, log, validate, or sql. Not used when the action type is rewrite, route-set, or setvar.

property.name: NamedInOutLocationType
property.description: Named Inputs and Outputs can be specified explicitly or dynamically, or can default to the unnamed regular input and output. Select the value appropriate for your WTX configuration.

property.name: NamedInputs
property.summary: Create all of the named inputs needed for the WTX transform.
property.description: Create all of the named inputs needed for the WTX transform.

property.name: NamedOutputs
property.summary: Create all of the named outputs needed for the WTX transform.
property.description: Create all of the named outputs needed for the WTX transform.

description.p: Specify the location of the resource (source or destination). Specify the location as either a URL or as a variable that expands to a URL. If a variable, use the var://context/name form.
Required for the fetch, log, results-async, and route-set actions. Optional for the results action. Not used for all other actions.

ul.li: For fetch, specify the source.
For route-set, specify the destination.
For log, results, and results-async, specify the destination (a foreign server to which to send the data).

description.p: Identify the schema with a URL (for example, store:///valHigh.xsd ) or with a variable in the form var://context/name which expands to a URL.
Used only when the action type is validate, identifies an XML schema used for document validation regardless of any xsi:schemaLocation attributes contained with the document.

property.name: WsdlURL
property.summary: The URL of the WSDL file
